text: What is a likely consequence of sudden braking?
options: There will be no consequences as the vehicle’s brake lights will come on.
The vehicle’s braking system could overheat.
The vehicle could be overtaken.
The vehicle could be hit from behind.
explanation: Watch for traffic behind you as well as in front. This helps you react safely if you must brake suddenly.

text: If the brake pedal of a vehicle feels soft or spongy when applied, what does this mean?
options: A fault in the brake fluid system.
The parking brake is on.
Worn brake pads.
A fault in the handbrake cable.
explanation: A soft or spongy pedal suggests low brake fluid or a system fault. Test brakes before every journey. Get faults checked immediately.

text: Whilst driving, why might a driver suspect that the brake fluid level in their vehicle is low?
options: The brakes take longer than usual to release.
The brakes feel spongy and soft.
The brakes feel hard to press.
The brakes are unusually sharp.
explanation: A soft or spongy pedal suggests low brake fluid or a system fault. Test brakes before every journey. Get faults checked immediately.

text: If a driver applies the footbrake and hears a scraping noise, what is the most likely cause?
options: One of the rear tyres is flat.
The brake linings or pads are worn.
The brake-pads are wet.
One of the front tyres is flat.
explanation: A scraping noise when braking likely means worn pads. This reduces safety. Have them replaced immediately.

text: What may indicate a problem with the vehicle’s braking system?
options: The vehicle’s parking brake is more effective.
The vehicle’s suspension is affected.
The vehicle’s stopping ability is affected.
The vehicle’s fuel consumption is reduced.
explanation: If the vehicle takes longer than usual to stop, the brakes may be faulty. Get them checked immediately.

text: What can cause a vehicle to skid?
options: Coasting to a stop.
Stopping in fourth gear.
Controlled acceleration.
Excessive heavy braking.
explanation: Heavy braking can cause skidding, especially on wet or uneven roads. Anticipate hazards early to avoid braking hard.

text: The parking brake (handbrake) generally works on which wheels?
options: The rear wheels.
All the wheels.
The rear right-hand wheel.
The front wheels.
explanation: The parking brake works on the rear wheels. Use it only when parked or stopped on a hill, never to stop a moving vehicle.

text: When should a driver have both hands on the steering wheel?
options: At all times except when using another vehicle control.
At all times except when on long straight roads.
Only when making a manoeuvre.
explanation: Keep both hands on the wheel at all times, except when changing gear, signaling, or using other controls.

text: What is the outcome of late clutch use when stopping a vehicle?
options: Tyres will wear down quicker.
The vehicle may cut out.
It helps to save fuel.
explanation: Use the clutch smoothy when changing gear. When stopping, press the clutch in time to prevent the engine from stalling.

text: What is the danger of sudden braking?
options: Driver’s airbag may deploy.
Vehicle may skid.
Handbrake may engage.
explanation: Always drive at a safe stopping distance. Sudden braking can cause you to lose control and skid.

text: When braking, what determines how quickly the vehicle will slow down and stop?
options: The amount of downward pressure applied to the brake pedal.
The amount of upward pressure applied to the brake pedal.
The amount of downward pressure applied to the accelerator.
explanation: The pressure on the brake pedal determines how quickly you stop. Brake progressively and in good time.

text: What should a driver be aware of when braking to slow down and stop?
options: An empty vehicle takes longer to stop.
A loaded vehicle takes longer to stop.
A shorter vehicle takes longer to stop.
explanation: A loaded vehicle takes longer to stop than an empty one. Allow extra distance such as on downhill slopes.

text: What should a driver do when a vehicle starts to aquaplane?
options: Ease off the accelerator to slow down.
Maintain speed to avoid skidding.
Brake firmly in order to slow down.
explanation: Aquaplaning happens when water builds up under tyres. If it happens, ease off the accelerator, don't brake, and steer gently.

text: What is the purpose of electronic stability control?
options: To keep the vehicle steady and prevent skidding.
To maintain speed when motorway driving.
To reduce fuel consumption.
explanation: ESC prevents skidding by applying brakes to individual wheels. It stabilises the vehicle in critical situations.

text: What is the most common cause of skidding?
options: Excessive speed for the circumstances or conditions.
Hot brake pads from over use on downhill stretches.
Badly worn brake pads.
explanation: Excessive speed reduces tyre grip and causes skidding. Adjust speed for wet, icy, or uneven roads.

text: When using the accelerator, how can a driver help reduce the vehicle’s fuel consumption?
options: A driver should accelerate smoothly to reach and maintain the appropriate speed.
A driver should accelerate quickly to reach the appropriate speed and then ease off to maintain pace.
A driver should accelerate smoothly only when the vehicle is laden.
explanation: Accelerate smoothly to reduce fuel consumption and wear. Your driving style impacts efficiency most.

text: Why should a tractor be driven more slowly on uneven road surfaces?
options: To maintain tyre pressure.
To reduce road noise.
To avoid severe bouncing.
To avoid fuel spilling from the tank.
explanation: Drive tractors slowly on uneven ground to prevent bouncing and loss of control.

text: When should the handbrake be used to bring a vehicle to a halt?
options: Only when going downhill.
Normally never.
At any time.
Only when going uphill.
explanation: Never use the handbrake to stop a moving vehicle. It can cause skidding and doesn't light up brake lights.

text: What is the danger associated with applying the handbrake (parking brake) when the vehicle is moving?
options: There is no danger - the vehicle will not skid as the handbrake can be released quickly.
The engine will stall once the handbrake is applied at speed.
The wheels could lock and cause the vehicle to skid.
The ABS could disconnect and cause the vehicle to skid.
explanation: Using the handbrake while moving can lock the rear wheels and cause a skid. It also gives no warning to drivers behind.

text: What is the recommended method of driving a car with automatic transmission?
options: Operate the accelerator with the right foot and the brake with the left foot.
Operate the accelerator and brake with the left foot.
Use the handbrake to bring the vehicle to a halt.
Operate the accelerator and brake with the right foot.
explanation: In an automatic, use your right foot for both accelerator and brake. Never use both pedals at once.

text: What is the effect of an incorrectly adjusted driver’s seat?
options: It gives the driver a better view in the rear-view mirror.
It improves the driver’s ability to operate the clutch.
It enables the driver to relax more on a long journey.
It can delay the driver from operating a control.
explanation: Adjust your seat so you can reach all controls comfortably and efficiently before starting.

text: What type of noise might fast cornering create?
options: Exhaust backfire.
Engine backfire.
Tyre squeal.
Brake squeal.
explanation: Tyre squeal on corners means you are driving too fast and losing grip. Slow down to maintain control.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Trams emerging from left.
Tram lane on left.
No parking inside the white line.
Bus and tram lane on left.
explanation: Tram lane on the left. Watch out for pedestrians crossing.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Radio transmission mast ahead.
Overhead electric cables.
Sharp corners ahead.
Crosswinds ahead.
explanation: Warning: Overhead electric cables. High vehicles must be careful.

text: Who can use a signed cycle track accompanied by a continuous white line on the left-hand side?
options: Cyclists and users of motorised wheelchairs.
Drivers when overtaking a vehicle turning right.
Cyclists and motorcyclists.
Drivers, when it is not being used by a cyclist.
explanation: Cycle tracks are for cyclists and motorised wheelchairs only. Do not drive on them unless entering a property/side road.

text: What lights indicate a zebra crossing?
options: Flashing amber beacons.
Flashing red beacons.
Continuously lit amber beacons.
Continuously lit red beacons.
explanation: Zebra crossings have flashing amber beacons. You must stop for pedestrians waiting or crossing.

text: What do temporary traffic lights at road works mean?
options: A driver must comply with the lights at all times.
A driver must comply with the lights when workers are on site only.
A driver need not comply if a convoy of traffic is going in the same direction.
A driver need only comply when there is oncoming traffic.
explanation: You must obey temporary traffic lights at roadworks. It is an offence to ignore them.

text: What do these signs together mean?
options: Parking not allowed during times shown.
Access for buses and taxis only during times shown.
Pedestrianised street ahead - traffic not allowed except during times shown.
Clearway ahead - no stopping or parking during times shown.
explanation: Pedestrianised street ahead. No vehicles allowed except during times shown on the plate.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Maximum permitted weight is 3 tonnes.
Minimum permitted weight is 3 tonnes.
3-axled vehicles are not permitted.
Only 3-axled vehicles are permitted.
explanation: Do not enter if your vehicle weighs more than 3 tonnes (3,000 kg).

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Passing other traffic that exceeds the weight shown is not allowed.
Parking in loading area is not allowed.
Parking of vehicles exceeding the weight shown is not allowed.
Parking of vehicles under the weight shown is not allowed.
explanation: No parking for vehicles over the weight limit shown.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No overtaking.
No stopping/parking on the right.
End of dual carriageway.
Double parking not allowed.
explanation: No overtaking. Used where visibility is reduced or overtaking is dangerous.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Only cyclists and buses are allowed to use the lane during the times indicated.
Only buses, cyclists and taxis are allowed to use the lane outside the hours indicated.
Only buses and cyclists may park during the times indicated.
Only buses, cyclists and taxis are allowed to use the lane ahead during the hours indicated.
explanation: With-flow bus lane on the left. Only buses, taxis, and cyclists allowed during operation hours.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Only double-decker buses and cyclists may use lane.
Cyclists and buses must turn left.
With-flow bus and cycle lane ahead on left.
Only buses and cyclists may park.
explanation: With-flow bus lane ahead on the left. Only buses, taxis, and cyclists allowed during operation hours.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Cyclists must give way to buses ahead.
Buses must give way to other traffic ahead.
Buses must give way to cyclists ahead.
Bus and cycle lane ahead on right.
explanation: Offside (right) bus lane ahead. Only buses, taxis, and cyclists allowed during operation hours.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Buses may block the driver’s view of cyclists.
With-flow bus lane on the left.
Contra-flow bus lane ahead.
With-flow bus lane on the right.
explanation: With-flow bus lane on the right. Only buses, taxis, and cyclists allowed during operation hours.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Cycle track may be crossed by buses.
With-flow bus lane to right.
Contra-flow bus lane on the right.
Buses emerging from right.
explanation: Contra-flow bus lane (buses move opposite to traffic). Do not use this lane.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Contra-flow bus lane.
With-flow bus lane.
Double-decker buses only.
Two-way traffic system.
explanation: Contra-flow bus lane (buses move opposite to traffic). Do not use this lane.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Tram lane on left.
Tram lane on right.
Parking only inside the white line.
With-flow bus lane ahead.
explanation: Tram lane on the right. Watch out for pedestrians.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Y-junction where main road bears to the left.
Y-junction where heavy vehicles must go left.
Y-junction where vehicles must go left.
Y-junction where main road bears to the right.
explanation: Y-junction ahead with a minor road. The wider arm shows the main road.

options: Junction ahead with dual carriageway.
Y-junction ahead with roads of lesser importance.
Y-junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
Minor road ahead.
explanation: Y-junction ahead with equal importance roads. Approach with caution and be ready to yield.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: T-junction ahead with roads of major importance.
Crossroads with major road ahead.
Crossroads with dual carriageway ahead.
Road passing under a bridge ahead.
explanation: Crossroads ahead with a major road. Be prepared to stop.

options: T-junction ahead with a road of minor importance.
T-junction ahead with a road of major importance.
Cul-de-sac to the right.
Cul-de-sac to the left and right.
explanation: T-junction ahead with a major road. Be prepared to yield or stop.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: T-junction with crossroads ahead.
Unguarded level crossing ahead.
Level crossing ahead guarded by gates.
Crossroads with dual carriageway ahead.
explanation: Crossroads ahead at a dual carriageway. Observe carefully and yield/stop as appropriate.

options: Guarded level crossing ahead.
Unguarded level crossing ahead.
T-junction with dual carriageway ahead.
Low bridge ahead.
explanation: T-junction ahead at a dual carriageway. Observe carefully and yield/stop as appropriate.

Traffic from the left has priority.

Diversion at junction ahead.
explanation: Merging and diverging traffic ahead. Watch for vehicles changing speed and direction.

Junction to the left.
Dangerous bend ahead.

Sharp change of direction to the left.
explanation: Sharp change of direction to the right. Slow down on approach.

End of dual carriageway.

explanation: Road narrows on the left. Be cautious and adjust your position.

Level crossing ahead protected by lights and barriers.
Railway station ahead.
explanation: Railway crossing ahead with lights and barriers. Prepare to stop.

Road damaged ahead.

Steep hills ahead.
explanation: Bumps or hollows ahead. Reduce speed.

Series of bends ahead.
explanation: Slippery road ahead. Drive with caution.

text: What does this sign mean?

Traffic signals ahead.

Stop at zebra crossing.
explanation: Traffic lights ahead. Be prepared to stop.

text: What does this sign mean?

School ahead.
Children’s play area ahead.
Pedestrian crossing ahead.
explanation: School ahead. Slow down and watch for children.

text: What does this sign mean?

Crosswinds ahead.
Airport ahead.
explanation: Crosswinds ahead. Slow down to maintain stability.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Low bridge 500 metres ahead.
Motorway ends 500 metres ahead.
No overtaking for 500 metres.
Bridge repair 500 metres ahead.
explanation: Motorway ends in 500m. Motorway rules will cease to apply.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: End of overhead bridge area.
End of motorway.
No bridges ahead.
No overtaking.
explanation: End of motorway. Motorway rules no longer apply.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Overtaking lane ends ahead.
A driver may overtake on the right only.
Road narrows from right.
Right-hand lane has an uneven surface.
explanation: Road narrows from the right ahead. Watch for hazards.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: End of dual carriageway ahead.
Road narrows on both sides.
Traffic merging from both sides.
End of obstruction between lanes.
explanation: Road narrows on both sides ahead. Slow down and drive with care.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Flagman ahead.
Hitch-hiking permitted.
Football stadium ahead.
Pedestrian crossing to right.
explanation: Traffic controlled by a flagman ahead. Obey their signals.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic may not stop.
Dual carriageway ahead.
One-way street.
Two-way traffic.
explanation: Two-way traffic ahead. Drive with extra care.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Nearside lane of two closed.
T-junction ahead in the left lane.
Offside lane of two closed.
Traffic in nearside lane must turn left.
explanation: Left lane closed ahead. Merge to the right when safe.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: End of dual carriageway.
Corner ahead on offside lane.
Offside lane closed ahead.
No stopping, except in offside lane.
explanation: Right-hand lane closed ahead. Watch for merging traffic.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Bend in the road to the left ahead.
Lay-by ahead.
Traffic should cross back to the left-hand lane ahead.
Slow lane ahead for heavy traffic.
explanation: Road returns to the left ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic should cross out to the right-hand lane ahead.
Bend in the road to the right ahead.
Traffic calming measures ahead.
End of “no overtaking” zone.
explanation: Road diverts to the right ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Tunnel ends ahead.
Dual carriageway ends ahead.
End of central reserve or obstruction.
Beware of vehicle with a wide load.
explanation: Traffic reverts to two-way ahead.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to slow down.
The cyclist intends to move out or turn right.
The cyclist intends to move in or turn left.
explanation: Cyclist intends to move out or turn right. Watch out.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist is signalling following traffic to overtake.
The cyclist intends to slow down or stop.
The cyclist intends to move out.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
explanation: Cyclist intends to slow down or stop. Be cautious.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The driver intends to proceed straight ahead.
The driver intends to turn left.
The driver intends to slow down or stop.
The driver intends to reverse.
explanation: Driver intends to go straight ahead.

text: What does this traffic light mean?
options: Traffic turning left should prepare for full green to move off.
Traffic is not allowed to turn left.
All traffic must turn left only.
Traffic turning left may proceed if the way is clear.
explanation: Green arrow means proceed safely in that direction.

text: When traffic lights are green, when should a driver not proceed?
options: When oncoming traffic is waiting to turn left.
When traffic is stopped waiting to turn from the road on the right.
When it would be unsafe to do so.
When traffic is stopped waiting to turn from the road on the left.
explanation: Do not enter a junction if it is not clear, even on green.

text: Where is a driver allowed to park?
options: On a footpath.
Where there is a continuous white line along the centre of the road.
At road works.
Where the driver is not blocking other road users their view of traffic signals or the road ahead.
explanation: Never park on a continuous white line. It causes obstruction and danger.

text: What distance before a zebra crossing is parking prohibited?
options: 15 metres.
10 metres.
20 metres.
5 metres.
explanation: No parking 15m before or 5m after a pedestrian crossing.

text: Within what distance of a road junction is parking prohibited?
options: 15 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
10 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
5 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
20 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
explanation: No parking within 5m of a junction unless in a marked space.

text: Is a driver permitted to park at an entrance to a property?
options: Yes, outside business hours.
Yes, for 1 hour between 07:00 hrs to 23:30 hrs.
Yes, with the property owner’s consent.
Yes, for 1 hour between 23:30 hrs to 07:00 hrs.
explanation: Parking across an entrance is only allowed with the owner's consent.

text: When is parking permitted on a footpath?
options: It is never permitted to park on a footpath.
When cars are parked on both sides of the road.
When at least half of the footpath remains free for pedestrians.
When no more than half of the vehicle is on the footpath.
explanation: Parking on a footpath is never permitted. It endangers pedestrians.

text: When is double parking permitted?
options: When there is a hard shoulder.
When there are double yellow lines.
It is never permitted.
When there are double white lines.
explanation: Double parking is never permitted. It obstructs traffic and endangers others.

text: When is parking permitted at a taxi rank?
options: Parking at a taxi rank is prohibited unless driving a taxi.
When the rank is unoccupied.
When waiting to collect passengers from a taxi.
When parking for less than 15 minutes.
explanation: No parking at a taxi rank unless driving a taxi. It obstructs the rank.

text: When is parking permitted at a sharp bend?
options: Parking is never permitted at a sharp bend.
When drivers coming from behind can see the parked vehicle.
When the hazard warning lights of the parked vehicle are on.
When parking no more than 45 centimetres from the kerb or edge of the road.
explanation: Never park at a sharp bend. It endangers other road users.

text: When is parking permitted on the brow of a hill?
options: Only when there is no traffic on the road.
Parking is never permitted on the brow of a hill.
Parking is permitted when a vehicle has an efficient handbrake.
When the driver angles the wheels towards the kerb.
explanation: No parking on the brow of a hill. It hides your vehicle from approaching drivers.

text: What is the purpose of traffic calming measures?
options: To alert drivers to road flooding ahead.
To slow down traffic in the vicinity.
To inform the driver of an increased speed limit ahead.
To prioritise heavy goods traffic.
explanation: Traffic calming measures slow down traffic entering towns or villages.

text: When may a trailer be towed on a public road without a rear number plate?
options: When the tailboard is removed.
When carrying a load that overhangs the trailer.
Never, a number plate must always be displayed.
When being towed by an agricultural tractor.
explanation: Trailers must always display a clean and legible rear number plate.

text: What traffic may use a cycle lane accompanied by a continuous white line?
options: Cyclists and motorised wheelchairs.
Cyclists and taxis.
Cyclists and motorcyclists.
Buses and cyclists.
explanation: Only cyclists and motorised wheelchairs can use a mandatory cycle track.

text: Apart from cyclists and motorised wheelchairs, what other road users may use an unoccupied cycle lane accompanied by a broken white line?
options: Only moped riders and motorcyclists.
Only buses and taxis.
All drivers may make temporary use.
Only hackneys and taxis.
explanation: Drivers may use a cycle track with a broken white line temporarily if it is unoccupied.

text: When must drivers stop at an automated railway level crossing with barriers and red flashing lights?
options: Stop safely when the amber light shows, or when red lights start to flash.
When there are no lights visible.
When the red and amber lights stop flashing.
When the barrier is fully up.
explanation: Stop safely when amber or red lights flash.

text: At a railway level crossing with unattended gates, what should a car driver do?
options: Telephone the nearest railway station before opening a gate.
Open both gates and after passing the first, stop and close it.
Open both gates before proceeding to cross.
Drive halfway across and close the first gate before opening the second.
explanation: Stop, look, and listen. If safe, open both gates, cross, and close both gates.

text: What do flashing amber arrows indicate at a junction?
options: When safe, drivers should proceed in the direction indicated.
It is prohibited to proceed in the direction indicated.
Proceed smartly through junction to avoid delay.
The direction indicated is a cul-de-sac.
explanation: Proceed in the direction of the flashing amber arrow if safe.

text: When do temporary speed limits apply at roadworks?
options: During business hours only.
Only when road workers are on site.
Only when there is oncoming traffic.
For the duration of the roadworks.
explanation: Temporary speed limits apply for the duration of the roadworks.

text: What does a continuous white line along the centre of the road mean?
options: Traffic can overtake.
Parking allowed during business hours.
U-turn allowed during daylight hours.
No U-turn allowed.
explanation: Never U-turn on a road with a continuous centre white line.

text: When wanting to stop temporarily in a congested area where should the driver park?
options: Double park in a convenient place with your hazard lights on.
Park on the footpath so as not to impede the free flow of traffic in the road.
Park slightly up on the footpath with the hazard lights on.
Park in a safe, legal and convenient place.
explanation: Park only where safe, legal, and convenient. Hazard lights do not excuse illegal parking.

text: What is a clearway?
options: An area that is strictly reserved for the loading and unloading of HGVs.
An area where stopping and parking is not permitted during certain times.
An area where stopping and parking is reserved for buses and taxis only.
An area that is reserved for pedestrians and motorised wheelchairs.
explanation: A clearway keeps traffic moving. Stopping or parking is prohibited during the times shown.

text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a toll plaza?
options: This lane closed - keep left.
Service station ahead.
Toll collector operating lane.
Garda checkpoint to the left.
explanation: Toll collector lane. Use if you don't have exact change or a tag.

text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a toll plaza?
options: Cashier in this lane.
Ticket dispenser in this lane.
Coin basket in this lane.
Electronic toll collection.
explanation: Coin basket lane. Use exact change here. Often has a height barrier.

text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a toll plaza?
options: Electronic toll accepted in any lane.
Electronic toll not accepted in this lane.
Electronic toll out of order in this lane.
Payment in euros only in this lane.
explanation: Electronic tag lane only. No cash payment.

text: What does a flashing amber arrow pointing left at a traffic light mean?
options: A driver may proceed before traffic on the other road.
The driver must wait until the traffic lights turn green.
A driver may turn left but must yield to traffic on the other road.
A driver must not proceed in this direction.
explanation: Amber arrow left: You may turn left but must yield to other traffic/pedestrians.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Bridge ahead.
Entry to motorway.
End of motorway.
explanation: Entry to motorway. Motorway rules apply.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Minor road ahead.
Start of dual carriageway.
Y-junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
explanation: Y-junction with equal importance. Be prepared to yield.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Roundabout ahead.
Ring road ahead.
Loop road ahead.
explanation: Roundabout ahead. Yield to traffic on the roundabout.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Mini-roundabout ahead.
Roadworks ahead, diversion in operation.
Loop road ahead.
explanation: Mini-roundabout ahead. Yield to traffic on the roundabout.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Automatic level crossing ahead.
Unguarded level crossing ahead.
Attended level crossing ahead.
explanation: Automatic level crossing ahead. Prepare to stop.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Steep descent ahead.
Unprotected quay, canal or river ahead.
Road likely to flood.
explanation: Unprotected water ahead. Be extremely cautious.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Deer or wild animals ahead.
Cattle and farm animals ahead.
Stag hunting ahead.
explanation: Wild animals like deer may be on the road. Be ready to stop.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Roadworks ahead.
Building site ahead.
Flagman ahead.
explanation: Roadworks ahead. Watch for machinery, workers, and surface changes.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: With-flow bus and cycle lane on left.

All roads except motorways.

A red L on a transparent background.
A white L on a red background.
A red L on a white background.

text: Which roads are learner permit holders not allowed to drive on?
options: They may not drive on national roads.
They may not drive on dual carriageways.
They may not drive on rural roads.
They may not drive on motorways.
explanation: Learner drivers must not drive on motorways.

options: No, only vintage vehicles are exempt from displaying a tax disc.
Yes, but for not more than 10 days after the expiry of the previous disc.
Yes, but for not more than one month after the expiry of the previous disc.
No, all motor vehicles must display a current tax disc.
explanation: Motor vehicles must display a current tax disc.

text: If a driver wishes to drive a vehicle but the tax disc is expired, what should they do?
options: They should tax it immediately.
They should drive it only in case of an emergency.
They should contact the Gardaí for approval.
They should renew it within 10 days of expiry.
explanation: A vehicle must be taxed and display a current disc before driving.

text: If a driver wishes to drive another vehicle which is not currently taxed, would they be allowed to transfer the current tax disc from their own vehicle onto it?

Only on a temporary basis if the other vehicle is subject to a lower rate of tax.
explanation: Tax discs are not transferable between vehicles.

text: When a vehicle is being driven by a person who is not the owner, who is responsible for ensuring that the vehicle is taxed and that a current tax disc is displayed?

The driver is the only one responsible.
The Gardaí have total responsibility in this area.
The driver and/or the owner of the vehicle are responsible.
explanation: Both owner and driver are responsible for tax and displaying the disc.

text: When must a current tax disc be displayed on a new vehicle on a public road?

Only when driving on motorways.
Not later than 10 days after registration.
explanation: A current tax disc must be displayed at all times on public roads.

options: The insurance company.
The driver and the vehicle owner.
The vehicle owner only.
The driver only.

text: Is a driver still insured to drive their vehicle after their insurance policy has expired?
options: The driver is insured up to 7 days after the expiry of the policy.
The driver is not insured after the expiry of the policy.

The driver is insured up to 10 days after the expiry of the policy.
explanation: You are not insured after your policy expires.

Drive if there is an insurance disc on the vehicle.
Transfer the insurance disc from their own vehicle on to the vehicle they wish to drive.
Drive it provided that they tell their insurance company within 10 days and agree to pay any additional premium.
explanation: Check with your insurer if you are unsure about your cover.

text: When a driver wishes to drive a vehicle and they are not sure if they are covered by insurance, what should they do?

They should check with their local Garda station to see if they are insured.

They should check with their local NDLS office to see if they are insured.
explanation: Do not drive until you confirm you are insured.

text: What is the minimum insurance cover a driver needs to drive on a public road?

Comprehensive.
Personal accident.
explanation: Minimum insurance required is Third Party.

text: If a driver passes their test using a vehicle with automatic transmission, which vehicles are they licensed to drive?

All vehicles in the licence category.

Only automatic vehicles in the licence category.
explanation: Passing on an automatic limits you to automatic vehicles only (Code 78).

explanation: Gardaí, Fire Brigade, and Ambulance are exempt from speed limits in emergencies.

By checking the unladen weight of the vehicle.

Only when the passenger holds a Category AM driving licence and the vehicle is designed to carry a passenger.

3,500 kilograms
explanation: Category B limit is 3,500 kg gross weight.

The driver must give way to traffic coming from the right.
explanation: STOP sign: You must stop your vehicle completely.

text: What must a driver do when this sign is accompanied by a white stop line on the road?
options: Stop at the line only if you see traffic approaching.
Stop past the line.
Stop at the line.
explanation: Stop at the white line when accompanied by a STOP sign.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No height restriction ahead.
No entry ahead.
Cul-de-sac ahead.
explanation: No entry. Do not proceed in this direction.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No right turn.
Cul-de-sac to the right.
Turn right only.
explanation: No right turn allowed.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Maximum speed is 30 km/h.
Minimum speed is 30 km/h.
Speed limit continues for 30 kilometres.
explanation: Max permitted speed is 30 km/h (Slow Zone).

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Speed limit continues for 50 kilometres.
Minimum speed is 50 km/h.
Maximum speed is 50 km/h.
explanation: Max permitted speed is 50 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Minimum speed is 60 km/h.
Maximum speed is 60 km/h.
Speed limit continues for 60 metres.
explanation: Max permitted speed is 60 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Speed limit continues for 80 metres.
Maximum speed is 80 km/h.
Minimum speed is 80 km/h.
explanation: Max permitted speed is 80 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Minimum speed is 100 km/h.
Maximum speed is 100 km/h.
Speed limit continues for 100 metres.
explanation: Max permitted speed is 100 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Parking is not allowed.
Private vehicles parking only.
Public service vehicles parking only.
explanation: Parking is prohibited in both directions.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Stop and wait for green light before proceeding.
The driver must stop when red lights show.
Stop and wait for amber light before proceeding.
explanation: Stop when red lights show (e.g., at level crossings).

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist intends to turn right.
The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
explanation: Cyclist intends to turn left.

text: What does this traffic light mean?
options: The driver must stop and wait until the full green light appears.
The driver may proceed in the direction of the green arrow if the way is clear.
The driver must divert to the right.
explanation: Green arrow: Proceed in direction of arrow if safe.

text: What does this traffic light mean?
options: Traffic must proceed if safe to do so.
Traffic may stop if safe to do so.
Traffic must stop at the traffic light.
explanation: Red light: Stop. Do not pass the line or light.

text: What road users must comply with traffic lights (including pedestrian lights)?
options: All road users.
Drivers and cyclists only.
Drivers and pedestrians only.
explanation: All road users, including pedestrians, must obey traffic controls.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Slippery road up ahead.
Uneven surface on left.
Loose chippings on road.
explanation: Loose chippings ahead. Reduce speed.

text: When must the holder of a learner permit display L plates on their car?
options: When driving unaccompanied by a full licence holder.
When driving on their first learner permit.
At all times when driving.
explanation: Learners must display L plates front and rear at all times.

text: When can a child under the age of sixteen drive a tractor on a public road?
options: Children under 16 are not allowed to drive a tractor on a public road.
A child under 16 is allowed to drive a tractor on a public road when they hold a learner permit.
A child under 16 is allowed to drive a tractor on a public road when accompanied by a fully licensed driver.
explanation: Under 16s cannot drive a tractor in a public place.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Pass on the left.
Steep decline to the left.
Keep left.
explanation: Keep left.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Steep decline from the left.
Traffic crossing from the left.
Keep right.
explanation: Keep right.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No right turn.
Turn right ahead.
Dangerous bend to the right ahead.
explanation: No right turn allowed.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No left turn.
Turn right only.
No right turn.
explanation: No left turn allowed.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic merging at 120 metres ahead.
Minimum speed is 120 km/h.
Maximum speed is 120 km/h.
explanation: Max permitted speed is 120 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Parking prohibited at the times shown.
Parking permitted during the times shown.
Maximum parking for one hour during times shown.
explanation: Parking permitted only at times shown.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Road closed during the times shown.
Pedestrianised street - no access for vehicles.
Clearway - no stopping or parking during the times shown.
explanation: Clearway: No stopping or parking at times shown.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Roads closed ahead to both left and right.
Cul-de-sac to both left and right.
Staggered crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.
explanation: Staggered junction ahead. Watch for emerging vehicles.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Dual carriageway ends.
Road narrows ahead.
Tunnel ahead.
explanation: End of dual carriageway. Two-way road ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Three lanes ahead.
Crossing traffic ahead.
Three hundred meters to the next exit.
explanation: Motorway exit 300 metres ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: 100 metres to the next exit.
Sharp descent for 100 metres.
Low bridge ahead.
explanation: Motorway exit 100 metres ahead.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to cross the road.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
explanation: Cyclist intends to turn left.

text: What does this Garda signal mean?
options: Stop if approaching from the front.
Stop if approaching from behind.
Proceed if approaching from the front.
explanation: Stop (when approaching Garda from front).

text: What does this road marking indicate?
options: Traffic calming.
Pedestrian island.
Zebra crossing.
explanation: Zebra crossing. Yield to pedestrians.

text: What is the maximum speed allowed for cars and motorcycles on motorways?
options: 80 km/h.
60 km/h.
explanation: Max speed 120 km/h on motorways.

text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum speed allowed for cars or motorcycles on national roads?
options: 80 km/h.
60 km/h.
explanation: Max speed 100 km/h on national roads.

text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum speed allowed for a car towing a caravan on national roads?
options: 60 km/h.
80 km/h.
explanation: Max speed 80 km/h when towing a caravan on national roads.

text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum speed allowed for a car towing a caravan on a motorway?
options: 90 km/h.
80 km/h.
explanation: Max speed 80 km/h when towing a caravan on a motorway.

text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum speed allowed for a car towing a trailer on a motorway?
options: 60 km/h.
80 km/h.
explanation: Max speed 80 km/h when towing a trailer on a motorway.

text: Who is authorized to see a driver’s vehicle registration document?
options: A member of the car recovery company or anyone assisting in the recovery.
A Garda may ask you to produce the vehicle’s registration document at a named Garda station.
Any Fire Brigade or Ambulance personnel at the scene of a collision the driver has been involved in.
Any person with whom the driver is involved in a collision.
explanation: A Garda may demand to see your licence, insurance, tax, NCT, and registration document.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Straight ahead only.
Height restriction ahead.
Motorway ahead.
explanation: Straight ahead only.

text: What effect does carrying a load have on a vehicle’s braking ability?
options: It increases the efficiency of the brakes.
It increases the distance required to stop.
It reduces the distance required to stop.
It has no effect provided the brakes are good.
explanation: Loads increase stopping distance. Increase your following distance.

text: What effect does towing a loaded trailer have on stopping ability?
options: It increases the efficiency of the brakes.
It reduces the stopping distance.
It increases the stopping distance.
It has no effect on stopping distance.
explanation: Towing a loaded trailer increases stopping distance. Increase your following distance.

text: Which of the following statements is true in relation to tyre pressure and driving on a motorway?
options: The driver should increase the rear tyre pressure in order to cope with sustained high speed.
The driver should reduce tyre pressure because high speeds will cause them to heat up.
The driver should ensure that tyre pressure is correct, in line with the manufacturer’s recommendations.
The driver should increase the front tyre pressure in order to cope with sustained high speed.
explanation: Ensure tyre pressure is correct at all times, especially on motorways.

text: What should a driver do when involved in an incident where nobody is injured but the vehicles are causing a danger or obstruction on the road?
options: Halt all traffic until it has been established who is at fault.
Take care when moving damaged vehicles and make every effort to warn other traffic.
Move all passengers and put a red warning triangle on the road.
Wait for the Gardaí to arrive before moving the vehicles.
explanation: Move vehicles to the side of the road to avoid obstruction.

text: What should a driver do if involved in an incident where there is damage to property only?
options: There is no need to report the incident if there is no damage to the vehicle.
It is only necessary to report the incident to the Gardaí within 10 days.
It is not necessary to report it to the Gardaí provided it has been reported to the property owner.
Report the incident both to the property owner and the Gardaí within 48 hours.
explanation: Report to the property owner or the Gardaí.

text: What should a driver do where a person has been injured in a collision?
options: Move the victim only if there is a risk of fire or further injury.
Always move the victim and the vehicles.
Move the victim to the side of the road.
Move the vehicles out of the way to avoid causing obstruction.
explanation: Do not move an injured person unless there is immediate danger. Call emergency services.

text: What type of drink should be given to a person who has been injured in a collision?
options: A hot drink.
A cold drink.
A non-alcoholic drink.
No drink should be given.
explanation: Do not give any drink to an injured person. Call emergency services.

text: What should a driver do to assist a person who is unconscious following a collision?
options: Try to keep the person warm with a blanket or overcoat.
Move the person to the nearest hospital immediately.
Try and get the person to drink something warm.
Raise the person’s head and hold it in that position.
explanation: Keep the person warm. Call emergency services.

text: If a driver is involved in a serious collision with an uninsured motorist, where nobody is injured, who should it be reported to?
options: The National Driver Licence Service (NDLS).
The local Motor Taxation Office.
The Irish Insurance Federation.
The driver’s insurance company and the Gardaí.
explanation: Report to the Gardaí and your insurance company.

text: What should a driver do if involved in a collision with another vehicle where nobody is injured?
options: Submit a written report to the Insurance Bureau of Ireland.
Give their name and address only to the other person.
Exchange all relevant details with the other driver.
Exchange no details but report the incident to the Gardaí.
explanation: Exchange all details: name, address, reg, and insurance.

text: What should a driver do if they arrive at the scene of a collision involving a vehicle carrying hazardous materials?
options: Keep well clear and call the emergency services.
Try to move the vehicle to a safe place.
Contact the haulage company who own the vehicle.
Try to prevent any further leakage of hazardous materials before raising the alarm.
explanation: Keep clear, call emergency services (999/112), and warn others.

text: How does the driver know the vehicle’s total load-carrying capacity?
options: By referring to the vehicle manufacturer’s specification.
By measuring the size of the boot.
By counting the number of seats.
By checking the horse power of the engine.
explanation: Design Gross Vehicle Weight = unladen weight + max load.

text: What determines the maximum allowed towing capacity of a vehicle?
options: The size of the tyres on the vehicle.
The combined weight of the vehicle and its trailer.
The manufacturer’s specifications.
The strength of the tow bar.
explanation: Max towing limit is specified by the manufacturer (handbook/plate).

text: What effect can overloading a vehicle have on its road-holding?
options: Provided the load is evenly distributed, it improves the stability of the vehicle.
The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control.
The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control, but only when going downhill.
The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control, but only when reversing.
explanation: Overloading makes the vehicle harder to control and is an offence.

text: What would be the effect of overloading a vehicle with passengers or goods?
options: It would improve the vehicle’s road-holding ability.
It would not have any effect provided speed is reduced.
Overloading will not reduce the ability to control the vehicle.
It would reduce the driver’s ability to control the vehicle.
explanation: Overloading reduces control and increases collision risk.

text: What effect could an unevenly distributed load have on a vehicle?
options: It could make the vehicle unstable while turning.
It could cause the clutch to slip while accelerating.
It could cause the vehicle to overheat.
It could cause the gear box to overheat.
explanation: Uneven loads affect stability, braking, and steering.

text: Why is it important to ensure that the vehicle headlights are correctly aligned?
options: To increase the lifespan of the headlights.
To enable the driver to see properly.
To reduce battery consumption.
To enable the driver to drive faster in the dark.
explanation: Correct alignment prevents dazzling others and ensures good visibility.

text: In general, how frequently should a vehicle’s lights be checked?
options: When wintertime approaches.
Daily before driving.
At major service intervals.
At minor service intervals.
explanation: Check lights daily.

text: What effect can a broken lens have on headlights?
options: It can cause the bulb to overheat.
It can reduce and distort the beam.
It can increase the brightness of the beam in the other headlight.
It can cause other bulbs to blow if not fixed immediately.
explanation: Broken lenses should be repaired immediately.

text: A driver wishes to drive at night, but the offside (right-hand side) headlight bulb is blown. What should the driver do?
options: Not drive until the bulb is replaced.
Replace it temporarily with the brake-light bulb.
Drive with the hazard lights on.
Replace it temporarily with the nearside (left-hand side) bulb.
explanation: Do not drive until the bulb is replaced.

text: How would a driver know that a brake-light bulb is not working?
options: They would notice the brake pedal become firmer under pressure.
They would notice the brake pedal getting softer under pressure.
By standing at the rear of the vehicle and checking as another person presses the brake pedal.
By standing at the rear of the vehicle and getting another person to turn on side lights.
explanation: Check brake lights with the help of another person or a reflection.

text: What does this light mean?
options: The gear box is over-heating.
The oil level is too low.
The engine is over-heating.
The battery is not charging.
explanation: Battery warning light: Charging system fault. Check immediately.

text: What does this light mean?
options: The high-beam headlights are switched on.
The reversing light is switched on.
The headlight beam should be dipped.
The number plate light is faulty.
explanation: Full beam headlights are on.

text: What does this light mean?
options: Low engine oil level.
Low engine coolant level.
Low brake fluid level.
Low battery fluid level.
explanation: Oil warning light: Low oil pressure. Stop immediately.

text: What does this light mean?
options: Right-hand fog light on.
Directional indicator on.
Brake light bulb blown.
Headlight bulb blown.
explanation: Indicator warning light. Cancel after turning.

text: What should a driver do if a system warning light lights up on the dashboard of their vehicle whilst driving?
options: Continue for a distance to see if the light goes out.
Continue to drive and listen for any unusual sounds.
Carry on and check the problem later.
Stop and check the problem.
explanation: Stop safely and investigate.

text: What should a driver do if a red system warning light lights up on the dashboard of their vehicle?
options: Continue on and see if it goes out.
Stop and investigate the cause.
Drive to the nearest garage and have it checked.
Continue on and listen for any unusual sounds.
explanation: Red warning light: Stop safely and investigate immediately.

text: What is the purpose of the red reflectors at the rear of a vehicle?
options: They warn the driver behind to switch to main beam.
They reflect light at night to make other road users aware of the vehicle.
They warn pedestrians of the vehicle’s location.
They are a substitute in case of brake-light failure.
explanation: Red reflectors maintain visibility for other road users.

text: If, when driving along, the driver notices that the engine power is lower than normal, what should they do?
options: Switch to a different fuel.
Have the vehicle checked by a competent person.
Replace the engine oil filter.
Adjust the fuel mixture control mechanism.
explanation: Loss of power: Have the vehicle checked.

text: While driving, the driver notices the vehicle temperature gauge showing red. What should they do?
options: Stop in a safe place and have the problem investigated.
Drive to the nearest service depot and top-up the water in the radiator.
Remove the filler cap from the radiator and check for leakage.
Do not drive until an anti-waxing agent is added to the coolant.
explanation: Temperature gauge red: Engine overheating. Stop immediately.

text: What should a driver do if they notice steam rising from the engine compartment?
options: Remove the filler cap from the coolant bottle.
Increase speed to increase the air flow into the engine compartment.
Stop where safe and investigate the cause.
Top up with anti-freeze immediately.
explanation: Steam means overheating. Stop and wait for it to cool. Do not open radiator.

text: If a driver notices that structural parts of their vehicle’s body have been affected by rust, what should they do?
options: Have paint sprayed over it of the same colour.
Have it repaired by a competent repair shop.
Have it sandpapered and keep the affected area dry.
Treat the area with grease and paint over it.
explanation: Rust should be repaired to prevent structural weakness.

text: After changing a wheel on a vehicle, which of the following should be checked soon afterwards?
options: The wheel nuts.
The tyre tread depth.
The air valve.
The brake pad clearance.
explanation: Check wheel nuts shortly after changing a wheel.

text: In general, how often should a driver check the tyre pressure of a vehicle?
options: Monthly.
Six monthly.
Annually.
Regularly.
explanation: Check tyre pressure weekly.

text: What is the main reason for maintaining the correct tyre pressures?
options: To help provide optimum road holding.
To reduce engine wear.
To stop the vehicle from sloping to the left.
To help maintain the correct ground clearance.
explanation: Correct pressure ensures optimum road holding and braking.

text: A fault in which component may lead to uneven or excessive tyre wear?
options: Clutch.
Suspension.
Accelerator.
Gearbox.
explanation: Worn suspension can cause uneven tyre wear.

text: What can be affected by driving on under-inflated tyres?
options: Oil pressure.
The exhaust system.
Fuel consumption.
The coolant system.
explanation: Under-inflated tyres increase fuel consumption and affect handling.

text: When should tyre pressure be checked?
options: When the tyres are part-worn.
When the tyres are cold.
At service intervals only.
When the tyres are hot.
explanation: Check tyre pressure weekly when tyres are cold.

text: During a weekly check, a driver notices a badly worn front tyre. What should the driver do?
options: Have the worn tyre replaced.
Fit the worn tyre on one of the rear wheels.
Reduce speed when driving on wet roads.
Check the tyre pressure to ensure it remains constant.
explanation: Replace worn tyres immediately.

text: What does worn tread along the edge of the inside of a tyre suggest?
options: Air pressure is high.
The vehicle has been driven too fast around corners.
Air pressure is low.
Steering alignment may be faulty.
explanation: Worn inside edge suggests a steering alignment fault.

text: With regard to tyres, what should a driver do before starting a long journey?
options: Check the tyres are inflated to normal air pressure.
Increase the air pressure in the tyres.
Reduce the air pressure in the tyres.
Reduce front tyre air pressure and increase rear tyre air pressure.
explanation: Check tyre inflation before long journeys.

text: What should the driver do to secure the vehicle when changing a front nearside (left-hand side) wheel?
options: Point the front wheels away from the kerb.
Ensure that the vehicle cannot roll when jacked up.
Ensure the gear lever is in neutral.
Point the front wheels towards the kerb.
explanation: Secure the vehicle (handbrake, gear, chock) on level ground.

text: What is the most common cause of heavy steering?
options: Over-inflated tyres.
Badly worn brakes.
Under-inflated tyres.
Poorly oiled steering.
explanation: Heavy steering is often caused by under-inflated tyres.

text: Which of the following is a driver required to keep in good condition?
options: Seatbelts.
Radio.
Paintwork.
Upholstery.
explanation: Seatbelts must be kept in good condition.

text: What should a driver do if condensation is affecting the vehicle’s windows?
options: Drive for a few kilometres with a window open.
Make sure that all demister vents and windows are closed.
Wipe the windows with the back of the hand.
Dry the windows with a cloth and then use the demister system.
explanation: Keep windows clean and use the demister/ventilation system.

text: What should a driver do if the right-hand headlight bulb fails when driving at night?
options: Drive with the hazard lights on.
Have the bulb replaced immediately.
Replace it temporarily with the left-hand headlight bulb.
Replace it temporarily with the brake light bulb.
explanation: Replace faulty headlight bulbs immediately.

text: A driver has stalled in the middle of an unguarded level crossing and cannot restart the engine. The warning bell is ringing. What should the driver do?
options: Stay at the vehicle and warn the approaching train.
Walk clear of the crossing and phone the signal operator so that trains can be stopped.
Push the vehicle clear of the crossing.
Try to restart the engine in first gear.
explanation: Get everyone out, call the signal operator, and warn trains.

text: When attaching a trailer to their vehicle, what must a driver check?
options: That the load is positioned to the rear of the trailer.
That the load is evenly spread.
That the load is positioned to the front of the trailer.
That the trailer has a spare wheel.
explanation: Distribute the load evenly over the axles.

text: When attaching a trailer to their vehicle, what must a driver check?
options: That the trailer coupling is attached securely.
That the load is positioned to the front of the trailer.
That the trailer springs are well greased.
That the trailer has a spare wheel.
explanation: Check tow bar, coupling, and breakaway cable.

text: What effect do the hazard warning lights have on the brake lights?
options: They have no effect.
They cause the brake lights to switch off completely.
They cause the left and right brake lights to flash alternately.
They cause the brake lights to flash repeatedly.
explanation: Hazard lights do not affect brake lights.

text: When should a driver use their hazard warning lights?
options: When the brake lights are not working.
When the vehicle has broken down.
When about to pull in and stop.
When parking for a short time on a single yellow line.
explanation: Use hazard lights to warn of a breakdown or danger.

text: When should a driver use their vehicle’s hazard warning lights?
options: When a following vehicle is too close.
When double parking.
When the brake lights are not working.
When causing an unavoidable obstruction.
explanation: Use hazard lights for unavoidable obstructions.

text: When should a driver use their vehicle’s hazard warning lights?
options: When parked at a bend or corner.
When reversing onto a narrow road.
When moving slowly in traffic.
When broken down and causing an obstruction.
explanation: Use hazard lights for obstructions or breakdowns.

text: What lighting must be on a two-axle car-trailer?
options: Indicators, brake lights, rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.
Indicators and rear number plate lights only.
Flashing rear tail lights.
Brake lights and indicators only.
explanation: Trailers need indicators, brake lights, tail lights, number plate light, and reflectors.

text: In general, how should children under 3 years of age be secured in a vehicle?
options: They should always be placed in the front passenger seat wearing a seat belt.
They should always be carried in an adult’s lap.
They should always sit on the rear passenger seat.
They should always be secured in the correct child seat.
explanation: Children under 3 must use an appropriate child restraint.

text: Can a child under the age of 3 years be carried unrestrained in the vehicle’s front passenger seat?
options: No, unless the child is using a child booster seat.
Yes, provided the infant is held securely by an adult.
No, an infant must always be restrained in the correct child seat.
Yes, but only if the vehicle is fitted with active airbags.
explanation: Children under 3 must be restrained. Never use rear-facing seats with active airbags.

text: If a vehicle breaks down, where should the driver stop?
options: As far to the left as possible.
As far to the right as possible.
In the lane where the problem occurred.
The nearest exit ramp.
explanation: Stop as far to the left as possible.

text: What is the quickest way to warn other traffic of a crash?
options: Use hazard lights.
Place a large object in the centre of the road.
Stand in the road and wave arms.
Call local radio station.
explanation: Use hazard lights to warn others.

text: In order to inform the emergency services of a crash what telephone number should be called?
explanation: Call 112 or 999.

text: When calling for help on an emergency telephone on the motorway, who does the call go to?
options: National Safety Council.
Road Safety Authority.
National Roads Authority.
The Gardaí.
explanation: Motorway phones connect directly to the Gardaí.

text: Where an injured person is discovered lying in the road, when should they be moved?
options: If the person is cold.
If the person needs CPR.
If the person has broken bones.
If the person is bleeding.
explanation: If not breathing, move to perform CPR. Otherwise, assess urgently before moving.

text: When dealing with crash victims, remember A B C. What does A stand for?
options: Airway.
Arms.
Accident.
Assist.
explanation: A = Airway, B = Breathing, C = Circulation.

text: What is good basic first aid for a person who has been burned?
options: Apply warm water to the burn.
Apply cold water to the burn.
Remove clothing covering the burn.
Apply grease to the burn.
explanation: Cool the burn with cold liquid. Seek medical advice.

text: What effect could hitting or mounting the kerb have on a vehicle’s tyres?
options: It could strengthen the sidewalls.
It could damage the sidewalls.
It could increase the air pressure.
It could wear the tread.
explanation: Hitting the kerb damages tyre sidewalls risk of blow-out.

text: Who should first be contacted where a person has been injured in a collision?
options: The person’s relatives.
The injured person’s insurance company.
The emergency services.
explanation: Call emergency services (999/112) immediately.

text: While driving, a driver notices a strong smell of fuel. What should they do?
options: Drive at a reduced speed.
Turn on the fan to clear the air.
Stop where safe and investigate.
explanation: Stop and investigate immediately.

text: What would make a pedestrian more visible to a driver at night?
options: Wearing a waterproof jacket.
Wearing headphones.
Wearing a hi-vis jacket.
explanation: Pedestrians should wear reflective strips/clothing at night.

text: Why should a driver adjust their head restraint before starting a journey?
options: To improve rear passengers view of the road ahead.
To provide support to the neck in the event of a collision.
To prevent glare from the headlights of following vehicles.
explanation: To reduce the risk of whiplash. Top of restraint should align with top of head.

text: What is the purpose of daytime running lights on a vehicle?
options: To give the vehicle extra light when driving at night.
To illuminate the road in bad weather conditions in daylight hours.
To increase the vehicles visibility in daylight hours.
explanation: To increase visibility to other road users during the day.

text: What is the immediate effect of a head-on collision between two cars at speed?
options: All persons in each vehicle are thrown violently backwards only.
All persons in each vehicle are thrown violently forward.
Only front seatbelts will activate.
explanation: Occupants are thrown violently forward.

text: Is it allowed for a vehicle to be driven on a public road when the brake lights are not working?
options: No, it is never permitted to be driven.
Yes, during lighting-up times.
Yes, outside of lighting-up times.
No, unless driving in a built-up area.
explanation: Brake lights must always be in working order.

text: Under what circumstances would a driver increase the air pressure in the tyres?
options: When the tread depth on the tyres is below 2 mm.
When taking a journey with additional passengers.
When the journey exceeds 200 km.
When higher speeds are expected on motorway driving.
explanation: Increase pressure for extra passengers or loads (see handbook).

text: How can sunlight affect visibility in a car with dirty windows?
options: It can enhance visibility.
It can seriously reduce visibility.
It can cause objects to seem further away than they are.
It can cause objects to seem closer than they are.
explanation: Dirty windows seriously reduce visibility, especially with sun glare or at night.

text: How does driving at high speed affect a vehicle’s road holding?
options: The suspension compensates for any unevenness in the road surface.
The wheel alignment keeps the tyres in full contact with the road.
The road holding ability of the vehicle is increased.
The road holding ability of the vehicle is reduced.
explanation: High speed reduces tyre grip and makes changing direction harder.

text: What effect could incorrectly aligned headlights have?
options: They could cause a fire.
They could reduce battery life.
They could wear out the bulbs prematurely.
They could dazzle oncoming drivers.
explanation: Healights must be aligned to see properly and not dazzle others.

text: What should a driver do before towing a caravan?
options: Ensure all passengers are securely seated in the caravan.
Have extended mirrors fitted to the towing vehicle.
Have an extended mirror fitted to the driver’s side of the vehicle only.
Ensure that only adult passengers are seated in the caravan.
explanation: Fit extended mirrors to both sides.

text: Generally what lighting must a car, tractor or works vehicle have when driving?
options: Headlights, front and rear side lights, rear number plate light, red rear reflectors, brake lights and indicators.
Headlights and a reversing light.
Headlights, number plate and rear reflectors only.
Headlights, brake lights and indicators only.
explanation: Headlights, side lights, number plate light, reflectors, brake lights, and indicators.

text: What danger could be associated with driving a tractor and trailer over a humpbacked bridge?
options: The tractor’s suspension could smooth out the bump.
The trailer could become detached.
The trailer could jack-knife.
The trailer’s parking brake could automatically engage.
explanation: The trailer could become detached if the hitch hits the road.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down on an automatic railway level crossing?
options: Walk along the track to give warning to any approaching trains.
Get passengers clear of the crossing and phone the signal operator so that trains can be stopped.
Try to push the vehicle clear of the crossing as soon as possible.
Turn on the warning bells at the crossing.
explanation: Get everyone out, call the signal operator, and warn trains.

text: What danger can arise from the power take-off shaft of a tractor?
options: If it is not disengaged, the steering will lock.
If it is not covered, clothing can get caught in it.
If it is not covered, the tractor will speed up rapidly.
If it is not disengaged, the battery will run flat.
explanation: Uncovered PTO shafts can catch clothing, causing injury or death.

text: When changing a wheel on a public road, what should a person do to ensure their own safety?
options: Ensure the vehicle is in reverse gear and front wheels are facing the roadway.
Ask a bystander to warn traffic by beckoning them from the middle of the road.
Wear reflective clothing and switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights.
Ensure the vehicle is in first gear and the wheels are facing the roadway.
explanation: Use hazard lights and wear reflective clothing.

text: What should a driver do when requested to drive a vehicle that they feel is overloaded?
options: Drive the vehicle only if accompanied.
Ensure that the load is properly restrained.
Drive at a slower speed than normal.
Refuse to drive the vehicle.
explanation: Do not drive an overloaded vehicle.

text: How could towing an overloaded trailer affect a vehicle?
options: It could improve braking ability when going downhill.
It could improve road holding on bends.
It could impair the vehicle’s steering and braking.
It could improve the vehicle’s fuel consumption.
explanation: It impairs stability, steering, and braking.

text: What should a driver do to secure the towing vehicle before unhitching a trailer?
options: Disconnect the electrical supply to the trailer lights and lower the jockey wheel.
Apply the handbrake, switch off the ignition and engage a low gear.
Lower the jockey wheel and then switch off the ignition.
Apply the handbrake, lower the jockey wheel and switch off the engine.
explanation: Apply handbrake, engine off, engage low gear.

text: What lighting must be on a tractors trailer during lighting-up hours?
options: Indicators, brake lights, rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.
Indicators, two white or yellow headlamps and rear number plate lights only.
An unloading light.
Brake lights and indicators only.
explanation: Indicators, brake lights, number plate light, reflectors, and tail lights.

text: What should a driver do to reduce the risk of neck injury in the event of a rear-end collision?
options: Use a properly adjusted head restraint.
Ensure the vehicle has a rear spoiler.
Use a properly adjusted seat belt.
Ensure the vehicle has anti-lock brakes.
explanation: Use a properly adjusted head restraint.

text: What is the minimum legal tread depth for tyres on cars?
options: 1 millimetre
1.6 millimetres
2.6 millimetres
0.6 millimetres
explanation: Minimum tread depth is 1.6 mm.

text: What does the load index of a tyre indicate?
options: The maximum load of the vehicle.
The maximum load per axle.
The maximum air pressure of the tyre.
The maximum load a tyre can carry.
explanation: The maximum weight the tyre can support safely.

text: A driver notices that the wiper blades are worn. What should they do?
options: Wipe the windscreen with newspaper.
Have the blades replaced as soon as possible.
Roll down the window and drive slowly.
Use the windscreen washer system while it is raining.
explanation: Replace worn wiper blades immediately.

text: When a wiper blade fails to clear the windscreen what should the driver do?
options: Have the wiper blades replaced as soon as possible.
Switch the wiper control from high speed to low speed repeatedly.
Apply a light film of oil to both of the wiper blades.
Bend the wiper arm to apply more pressure on the windscreen.
explanation: Replace the wipers.

text: If a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, what should a person do?
options: Place a red warning triangle on the motorway to warn other drivers.
Use a roadside phone to contact Gardaí and never try to carry out repairs yourself.
Ask a passenger to stand on the road to warn other traffic.
Turn on the full beam headlights to alert other drivers.
explanation: Move to hard shoulder, call Gardaí. Do not use a warning triangle on the motorway.

text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger over 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?
options: The driver when the passenger is in the front seat.
The passenger only.
Both the driver and the passenger.
The driver only.
explanation: Passengers over 17 are responsible for their own seat belts.

text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger under 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?
options: The driver only.
The driver, but only when the passenger is in the front seat.
The passenger only.
The passenger’s parents.
explanation: The driver is responsible for passengers under 17.

text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a child wears a child restraint system in a vehicle?
options: The driver only.
Any adult passenger.
The child, if over 12 years of age.
The parents of the child only.
explanation: The driver is responsible for child restraints.

text: How should a child restraint system be fitted in a vehicle?
options: It should be placed on a front passenger seat only.
It should be left unsecured.
It should be placed on the floor.
It should be fitted in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.
explanation: According to the manufacturer's instructions.

text: On a motorway, when should a driver use the hazard warning lights?
options: When parked in the hard shoulder to take a phone call.
When another vehicle is following too closely.
When the vehicle has broken down.
When towing another vehicle.
explanation: Use hazard lights to warn of a breakdown or danger.

text: If a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, what should a person do?
options: Turn on the full beam headlights.
Ask a passenger to stand on the motorway to warn other traffic.
Place a red warning triangle to the left of the vehicle.
Move the vehicle to the hard shoulder.
explanation: Move to hard shoulder, warn others (hazard lights).

text: If a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, what should a person do?
options: Turn on the full beam headlights.
Ask a passenger to stand on the motorway to warn other traffic.
Place a red warning triangle to the left of the vehicle.
Wear a high-visibility vest.
explanation: Move to hard shoulder, hazard lights, wear a high-vis vest.

text: Where safety belts are fitted to a car when must adult occupants wear them?
options: Only when instructed to do so by the driver.
When travelling on long journeys.
At all times.
explanation: Seat belts must be worn at all times.

text: What should a driver be alert to in this area?
options: Pedestrians may be hitch-hiking.
Parked vehicles may have trailers attached.
Pedestrians may cross between parked cars.
There may be refuse bins between the parked vehicles.
explanation: Watch for pedestrians crossing between parked cars.

text: The silver car is overtaking the parked red car, what should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver should drive on if he does not hit the ball.
The driver should move closer to the red car.
The driver should drive on at the same speed.
Reduce speed considerably and be ready to stop.
explanation: Slow down/stop. A child may follow the ball.

text: How should a driver overtake the cyclist in this situation?
options: Overtake the cyclist, but without crossing any of the lines.
By sounding the horn to warn the cyclist they intend to pass.
By straddling both lines and keeping close to the cyclist.
By crossing the broken white line.
explanation: Cross the broken white line to overtake if safe.

text: Why might it be dangerous to drive on a poorly-lit street?
options: Drivers can only see the traffic coming against them.
Drivers can only see the traffic in front of them.
It may be difficult to make out poorly lit vehicles in the dark areas.
Traffic lights will not be working.
explanation: Hazards (like unlit vehicles) are harder to see.

text: What should a driver do on the approach to this situation?
options: Increase speed in order to clear the bridge before the oncoming car.
Reduce speed and stop if necessary.
Give way only if you are towing a trailer or caravan.
Drive on because the oncoming traffic must wait.
explanation: Yield to oncoming traffic if priority is unclear.

text: Why must a driver be particularly careful here?
options: The vehicle coming from the right has the right of way.
The vehicle coming from the right is not required to signal.
Because there is an increased danger of skidding.
Because a vehicle could come from the left.
explanation: Wet leaves reduce grip and increase braking distance.

text: What should a driver do when turning right at this junction?
options: Proceed ahead of both cars.
Allow the blue car to proceed.
Allow the red car to proceed.
Allow both cars to proceed.
explanation: Yield to oncoming traffic on the main road.

text: What should a driver be aware of when driving at night along a shopping street with many different light sources?
options: Parking spaces may be difficult to notice.
Traffic lights may be difficult to distinguish from the other bright lights.
Other vehicles do not need to use their head lights.
It is easier to see pedestrians because of the bright lights.
explanation: Complex lighting can make traffic lights harder to see.

text: In this situation who should wait?
options: The driver behind the stopped van should wait.
Neither vehicle should wait.
Whichever vehicle is furthest away from the van.
The oncoming vehicle must wait.
explanation: Yield to oncoming traffic when passing an obstruction.

text: In this situation, who should wait?
options: Neither driver should wait.
Both drivers should wait.
The driver in the red car should wait.
The driver on the main road should wait.
explanation: Yield to traffic on the main road.

text: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
options: A minor road to the right ahead.
A sharp dip in the road ahead.
A dangerous right-hand bend ahead.
A minor road to the left ahead.
explanation: Red warning sign indicates a dangerous right-hand bend.

text: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from the major road into the minor road?
explanation: Position just left of centre before turning.

text: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from a minor road onto a major road?
explanation: Position just left of centre before turning.

text: What should a driver do if they see a red warning triangle on the road?
options: The driver should remove the triangle as it is causing an obstruction on the road.
The driver should stop and await instructions.
The driver should maintain speed, carry on and avoid the triangle.
The driver should slow down and expect a hazard up ahead.
explanation: Slow down and expect a hazard ahead.

text: What should drivers be aware of if they meet horses with riders on the road?
options: Drivers should be aware that horse riders are obliged to dismount and control their horses while traffic is passing.
Drivers should be aware that all horse riders are experienced at handling horses.
Drivers should be aware that loud noises from their vehicle may frighten the horses and cause them to bolt.
Drivers should be aware that loud noises from their vehicle will not frighten the horses.
explanation: Horses are easily startled; noise or sudden movements can cause them to bolt.

text: There are pedestrians on the footpath ahead and there are pools of water on the road. What should a driver do?
options: Reduce speed and try to avoid the pools of water so as not to splash the pedestrians.
Sound the horn as a warning to the pedestrians and continue on.
Flash the headlights as a warning to the pedestrians.
Brake suddenly as you approach the pools of water.
explanation: Reduce speed and avoid splashing pedestrians or cyclists.

text: When is it permitted to force oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder on the opposite side of the road while overtaking?
options: When the hard shoulder is wide enough.
When none of the oncoming traffic is overtaking.
When the vehicle being overtaken is driving too slow.
It is not permitted to force oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder while overtaking.
explanation: Overtaking dangerously is prohibited. Ensure road is clear without forcing others to alter course.

text: What does a 2-plus-1 road have?
options: Two non-motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.
Two motorway lanes and one non-motorway lane in two directions.
Two motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.
Two non-motorway lanes and one motorway lane in two directions.
explanation: Two lanes in one direction, one in the other, alternating every 2km.

text: Where may a driver overtake on a 2-plus-1 road?
options: In the two-lane stretch.
In the one-lane stretch if there is no oncoming traffic.
In the one-lane stretch.
In either the one-lane stretch or the two-lane stretch.
explanation: Overtake only in the two-lane section.

text: At road junctions, what type of road users are particularly vulnerable?
options: Car drivers.
Pedestrians.
Tractor drivers.
Van drivers.
explanation: Pedestrians, cyclists, and motorcyclists.

text: What should a driver do to ensure better fuel efficiency from their vehicle?
options: Ensure that the vehicle is regularly serviced.
