Ensure any load carried is equally distributed on the vehicle.
Drive at higher speeds in order to reduce the time spent on the road.
Ensure that heavier items are carried at the rear of the vehicle.
explanation: Ensure regular servicing and check tyre pressure.

text: In what way do motor vehicles harm the environment?
options: By decreasing radon levels.
By increasing carbon monoxide levels.
By decreasing carbon monoxide levels.
By increasing radon levels.
explanation: Exhausts emit poisonous carbon monoxide. Eco-driving reduces emissions.

text: What can be achieved by the driving style known as ‘Eco-Driving’?
options: Increased fuel consumption.
Reduced fuel consumption.
Increased journey times.
Reduced journey times.
explanation: Improved safety, fuel efficiency, and reduced emissions.

text: Which action contributes to eco-driving?
options: Braking harshly.
Selecting a high gear as soon as possible.
Driving in a low gear at high speed.
Fitting a roof rack.
explanation: Select the highest gear possible without labouring the engine.

text: When should a driver use dipped headlights?
options: From just after dusk to just before dawn.
From 00:00 hrs to 06:00 hrs.
When visibility is less than 200 metres.
When visibility is less than 300 metres.
explanation: During lighting-up hours (dusk to dawn).

text: What lights should a vehicle show at dusk?
options: Dipped headlights.
Fog lights.
Full headlights.
Daytime Running Lights (DRLs) only.
explanation: Dipped headlights.

text: An approaching driver notices that the boy on the children’s bicycle has said goodbye to his friend. What is the correct action for the driver to take?
options: Be prepared for the boy setting off at any moment.
Proceed as the boy is on the footpath.
Slow down and beckon the boy to cross the road.
Stop the car until the boy has moved off.
explanation: Be prepared for the child to move off suddenly.

text: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
options: The pedestrian may leave the traffic island without paying attention.
The tram may move away without warning.
The pedestrian always has the right of way to cross in front of traffic.
There is no danger as the tram is on rails.
explanation: Expect extra pedestrian activity near a tram stop.

text: What should the driver be most conscious of in this situation?
options: The pedestrian always has right of way to cross the road.
The pedestrian may suddenly cross the road in front of the vehicle.
No vehicles should be parked on the left-hand side of the road.
One of the parked vehicles may reverse into the driver’s path.
explanation: Be prepared to stop; parked vehicles obscure hazards.

text: What should the driver do when approaching this situation?
options: The driver should maintain current speed and reduce distance from the silver car.
The driver may overtake the car and the girl as the road is marked with a broken white line.
The driver should be prepared for the vehicle in front to increase speed.
Reduce speed and remain ready to brake since the girl on the footpath could suddenly cross the road.
explanation: Reduce speed and be prepared to brake for pedestrians.

text: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
options: A driver should move to the left-hand side (nearside) in case the cyclist moves out.
The cyclist may move onto the roadway without paying attention to moving traffic.
The cyclist will stop at the end of the cycle path to allow traffic to pass by.
The cyclist will stay on the cycle path.
explanation: Show extra care for cyclists exiting a cycle lane.

text: What should a driver be aware of when following the motorcyclist, and the white car is reversing onto the road?
options: The reversing driver will stop when they see the motorcyclist.
The driver following the motorcycle may need a longer braking distance than normal.
The motorcyclist may signal the reversing driver to stop.
The brake lights on the motorcycle may not be working.
explanation: Keep a safe distance and be prepared to react.

text: After a heavy downpour, why should a driver keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front?
options: Because required stopping distances are decreased.
Because wheels rotate at a greater speed after rain.
Because wheels rotate at a slower speed after rain.
Because wheel-spray may impair visibility.
explanation: Heavy rain reduces visibility and increases stopping distances. Slow down.

text: What should the car driver be aware of in this situation?
options: Slowing down and being prepared to react.
Following traffic may cut the corner.
The road ahead becomes a dual carriageway.
Road marking is taking place ahead.
explanation: Slow down at bends with restricted view.

text: What should a driver be most aware of in this situation?
options: A car might appear unexpectedly at the brow of the hill.
Children may unexpectedly run out from between parked cars.
One of the parked vehicles may reverse into the driver’s path.
Parking opposite double yellow lines is prohibited.
explanation: Watch for children playing in residential areas.

text: What should a driver who wants to turn right do in this situation?
options: Reverse and get into the right lane.
Proceed straight ahead and take a wide turn to the right.
Turn right from the left lane.
Proceed straight ahead or turn left.
explanation: Take up the correct position for turning in good time.

text: What should the driver do when there is a sharp dip in the road ahead?
options: Move to the centre of the road in order to avoid any vehicles that might be parked on the left.
Increase speed and make progress through the dip.
Pull in, stop and switch on hazard warning lights.
Reduce speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.
explanation: Reduce speed and be alert for hidden dangers like flooding or pedestrians.

text: The driver is approaching traffic lights that they know have been green for some time. What should the driver do?
options: The driver should be aware that the lights may change before they reach them and be prepared to stop.
The driver should stop as the lights are about to change to red.
The driver should be aware that the lights may change and accelerate to clear the lights before they do.
The driver should maintain speed until the light changes to amber.
explanation: Be prepared to stop, as the light is likely to change to amber.

text: What should a driver do when approaching a junction normally controlled by traffic lights and the traffic lights are not lighting?
options: Switch on headlights, move to centre of the junction and proceed as quickly as possible.
Treat it as an unmarked junction and proceed cautiously while watching out for other traffic.
Stop at the junction and give way to traffic on the left.
Proceed smartly through the junction to avoid delay.
explanation: Treat as an unmarked junction and proceed with caution if safe.

text: What should the driver do if there are cattle on the road ahead?
options: The driver should sound the horn to try to get the cattle to move aside.
The driver should switch on the headlights and try to pass as quickly as possible.
The driver should sound the horn, switch on headlights, reduce speed and pass with care.
The driver should reduce speed and pass them with care.
explanation: Slow down, do not use the horn, and be prepared to stop.

text: What should a driver do if they see horse riders on the road ahead?
options: The driver should increase speed and allow extra clearance.
The driver should reduce speed, allow extra clearance and pass with care.
The driver should turn on hazard warning lights and continue at normal speed.
The driver should reduce speed and sound the horn.
explanation: Reduce speed, allow extra clearance, and do not use the horn.

text: What should the driver do when approaching a humpbacked hill?
options: The driver should reduce speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.
The driver should move to the centre in order to avoid vehicles that may be parked on the left.
The driver should increase speed and make progress over the humpbacked hill.
The driver should maintain normal speed and road position.
explanation: Reduce speed, keep left, and watch for hidden dangers.

text: What do flashing amber beacons on an oncoming vehicle alert a driver to?
options: That the oncoming vehicle is fast moving.
That the oncoming vehicle is an emergency vehicle.
That the oncoming vehicle may be slow moving or extra wide.
That the oncoming vehicle is a military vehicle.
explanation: Slow moving, extra wide, or recovery vehicle. Slow down.

text: What should a driver do if they meet a vehicle with flashing amber beacons?
options: Flash their headlights to acknowledge the beacons.
Slow down and prepare to stop.
Increase speed while keeping left.
Stop because it is an emergency vehicle.
explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop.

text: What should a driver be aware of before crossing railway or tram lines?
options: The wheels may become caught in the rails, causing the tyres to deflate.
There may be a reduction in tyre noise while crossing the rails.
The tyre grip may be improved crossing the rails.
There may be an uneven surface and tyre grip may be reduced when crossing the rails.
explanation: Uneven surface or oil may reduce grip. Slow down.

text: What should the driver be aware of when crossing road markings such as lines and directional arrows in wet weather?
options: The required stopping distance is reduced due to improved tyre grip.
The tyre grip is improved.
The required stopping distance is increased due to reduced tyre grip.
Steering control is improved.
explanation: Road markings can be slippery when wet. Avoid skidding.

text: What should a driver do on a narrow road when another vehicle is coming in the opposite direction?
options: Maintain position and expect the other vehicle to move over.
Reduce speed and allow reasonable clearance between their vehicle and the oncoming one before proceeding.
Position your vehicle along the middle of the road to encourage the other driver to pull in.
Maintain road position and speed. Then flash the vehicle’s lights to alert the other driver to your presence.
explanation: Slow down and pass at a safe speed.

text: When a driver is driving behind another vehicle that they do not intend to overtake, what should the driver do?
options: Keep well back and to the centre of the road.
Drive close behind it in order to let following traffic overtake both vehicles.
Signal to following traffic to overtake both vehicles.
Keep well back to allow following traffic to overtake.
explanation: Keep a safe distance to stop and allow others to overtake you.

text: When a driver is driving in a line of traffic and does not intend to overtake, what should the driver do?
options: Drive close to the vehicle in front.
Stay back and leave a gap for other drivers to overtake.
Indicate left as a signal to following traffic to overtake.
Beckon to following traffic to overtake.
explanation: Keep back to allow others space to overtake.

text: Is tailgating allowed on a motorway or dual carriageway?
options: Yes, because all traffic moves in the one direction at the same time.
No, because the vehicle in front may stop suddenly.
No, because other vehicles do not have room to overtake.
Yes, because there is oncoming traffic.
explanation: Tailgating is dangerous. Use the two-second rule.

text: What danger can arise during daylight when a driver enters an area that is heavily shaded by overhanging trees?
options: Visibility could suddenly be reduced.
The vehicle’s windscreen could fog up.
The tyre pressure could be reduced.
The vehicle engine could suddenly run cold.
explanation: Visibility may be reduced, hiding hazards.

text: When driving into a narrow gap between oncoming vehicles and vehicles parked on the left. What should a driver do?
options: Indicate and drive on enforcing your priority.
Signal to oncoming traffic to stop, and then move to the right and drive as normal.
Always slow down, stop and wait to be beckoned forward.
Indicate right, stopping if necessary until oncoming traffic has passed by.
explanation: Slow down or stop to allow safe passing.

text: What should a driver do when approaching traffic lights stuck on red?
options: Stop and proceed with great caution.
Check that there are no oncoming vehicles and increase speed.
Sound the horn and proceed ahead.
Indicate and increase speed.
explanation: Stop, then proceed with caution when clear.

text: What should a driver do when there are dark clouds and visibility is reduced during daylight hours?
options: Drive with dipped headlights switched on.
Keep close to any vehicle in front with headlights off.
Driver should not switch on lights until lighting up hours.
Drive with main beam headlights switched on.
explanation: Turn on dipped headlights.

text: When driving behind a bus that is signalling to turn left and there is oncoming traffic, what should a driver do?
options: Stay back and allow it to complete the turn.
Overtake it on the left-hand side.
Overtake it on the right-hand side.
Tap the brakes and sound the horn to signal to other vehicles to slow down.
explanation: Stay back and allow the bus to complete the turn.

text: What should a driver do when driving on a wide road behind a vehicle that has signalled to turn right ahead?
options: Overtake on the right-hand side and carry on.
Stay behind and tap the brakes to signal other drivers to slow down.
Overtake on the left-hand side and carry on if safe to do so.
Overtake on the left, but only if turning left a short distance ahead.
explanation: Overtake on the left if safe and sufficient room exists.

text: When is it permissible to overtake another vehicle on the nearside (left-hand side)?
options: Only when there is no cycle lane.
A driver must never overtake on the left.
When the vehicle in front is signalling to turn right.
When there are three lanes available in fast moving traffic.
explanation: When the vehicle in front is turning right and there is room.

text: What should a driver who wishes to perform a U-turn do?
options: Check ahead for approaching traffic and signal them to stop.
Only perform a U-turn outside the urban speed limit area.
Check that the road is not one way.
Check behind for approaching traffic and signal them to stop.
explanation: Choose a safe, legal place and check for other road users.

text: What should a driver do if they are not travelling as fast as the vehicle in front?
options: The driver should keep to the left and allow vehicles to overtake if they wish.
The driver should keep their position and not allow following vehicles to overtake.
The driver should invite traffic to overtake them by giving a hand signal.
The driver should switch on hazard warning lights and keep to the left.
explanation: Keep left to allow others to pass safely.

text: What should a driver do if they wish to drive across a busy road and the traffic lights which normally control the junction are temporarily out of action?
options: Take good observation, wait for a clear break in the traffic and proceed to cross the road safely.
Switch on headlights and use hand signals to show other drivers their intention to cross and then proceed.
Slowly force their way across using hazard warning lights if necessary.
Sound the horn and proceed slowly to cross the road.
explanation: Wait for a clear break in traffic; do not assume priority.

text: What should a driver do if they see a school bus stopped on the nearside (left side) of the road ahead?
options: Signal and maintain current speed.
Reduce speed and overtake with caution.
Sound the horn as a warning and continue on.
Switch on hazard warning lights and stop behind the bus.
explanation: Reduce speed and caution for children.

text: What should the driver do when driving behind a vehicle that is going from side to side on the road in an unsafe manner?
options: The driver should signal and go around to the right of the vehicle.
The driver should stay well back in a safe position.
The driver should signal and go around to the left of the vehicle.
The driver should drive close behind the vehicle with a view to overtaking.
explanation: Stay safe distance back. Report to Gardai if safe.

text: What should a driver do if a heavy goods vehicle in front has moved out to make a left turn ahead?
options: Move to the right but do not overtake.
Stay behind it and allow it to complete the turn.
Drive into the space on its left-hand side.
Move out immediately and overtake as quickly as possible.
explanation: Stay behind until it completes the turn.

text: What should a driver do if a bus in front has moved out to make a left-hand turn and there is oncoming traffic?
options: Overtake on the left-hand side.
Overtake on the right-hand side.
Maintain speed until up close behind the bus.
Stay back and allow the bus to complete the turn.
explanation: Stay back; the bus needs extra space. Do not overtake.

text: What should a driver do if they are first in line to turn right at traffic lights while the green light is showing and there is oncoming traffic approaching?
options: Wait at the stop line for the light to turn amber and then make the turn.
Go forward towards the centre of the junction and turn safely when a suitable gap appears.
Remain at the stop line until a green arrow comes on.
Remain at the stop line until a suitable gap in the oncoming traffic appears before making the turn.
explanation: Move to the center and turn when safe.

text: When meeting oncoming traffic on a national road, is it permitted to move into the hard shoulder to allow following traffic to overtake?
options: Yes, when a truck or bus is oncoming.
No, except on ‘2-plus-1 roads’.
No, it is never permitted to drive on a hard shoulder except in the case of an emergency.
Yes, temporarily when the hard shoulder is clear and it is safe to drive there.
explanation: Yes, briefly, if safe and no pedestrians/cyclists/junctions.

text: When driving on a national road is it permitted to drive on the hard shoulder in order to allow faster-moving traffic to overtake?
options: Only when driving on a dual carriageway.
No, except when driving on a ‘2-plus-1 road’.
Yes, temporarily when the hard shoulder is clear and it is safe to drive there.
Only when a truck or bus wants to overtake.
explanation: Yes, briefly, if safe and clear.

text: What should a driver do in a queue of traffic controlled by traffic lights?
options: Put on a right signal to prevent following vehicles from overtaking.
Overtake on the right and move to the head of the queue if there is space available.
A driver should maintain their position in the queue.
Overtake on the left and move to the head of the queue if there is space available.
explanation: Maintain position; do not jump the queue.

text: Subject to the speed limit, what is the ‘safest’ speed to drive at?
options: The speed of the slowest vehicle on the road.
A driver should always try to drive at the speed limit for the road that they are on.
The speed that will enable the driver to stop the vehicle within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.
A driver should always try to drive at the speed of other road users, regardless of the speed limit.
explanation: Drive at a speed that allows you to stop within the distance you can see to be clear.

text: When driving along and wishing to use a hand-held mobile phone, what should a driver do?
options: Secure the phone between head and shoulders while steering with both hands.
Move the phone as needed and keep the call to just a few minutes.
Steer with one hand.
Stop at a safe location before using the phone.
explanation: Stop in a safe place before making a call.

text: When stopped at traffic lights and the green light comes on, what should a driver do?
options: Accelerate at a greater rate than other drivers so as to facilitate overtaking.
Move off slowly and then check the mirrors.
Check that other road users have cleared the junction and move off with care.
Move off quickly and then check the mirrors.
explanation: Ensure the way is clear and safe before proceeding.

text: What should a driver do if another vehicle blocks their right of way at a junction?
options: Pursue the vehicle and express displeasure.
Be patient and show restraint.
Flash the headlights to express displeasure.
Sound the horn and flash the lights to show your frustration.
explanation: Be patient and show restraint. Right of way is not absolute.

text: When being overtaken and there is oncoming traffic, what should a driver do?
options: Allow the overtaking vehicle to pass and return safely to the left side of the road.
Maintain position because other drivers should not have attempted to overtake.
Speed up so the following vehicle cannot overtake.
Maintain position and flash the headlights to warn the oncoming traffic.
explanation: Allow the overtaking vehicle to pass to avoid a collision.

text: What should a driver do when they get a puncture while driving?
options: Continue on your journey and arrange for repair when convenient.
If on a motorway, stop and change the wheel immediately.
Stop at a safe place and change the wheel.
Maintain speed until a place to change the wheel is identified.
explanation: Stop at a safe place to change the wheel.

text: What should a driver do when they want to safely change to the lane on the right in which there is other traffic?
options: Move gradually into the right-hand lane, indicate and then check mirrors.
Pull in and stop, wait until a suitable gap appears and then move out to the right-hand lane.
Increase speed until travelling at the same speed as the traffic in the right lane, then move over and check mirrors.
Use the mirror, signal and move into the right-hand lane when a suitable gap appears in the traffic in that lane.
explanation: Mirror, Signal, Mirror, Manoeuvre. Move when a suitable gap appears.

text: What effect does alcohol have on driver behaviour?
options: It can increase perception and awareness.
It slows down a driver’s reactions.
It does not affect driver behaviour or ability.
It can reduce a driver’s confidence.
explanation: Alcohol slows reactions and affects judgement.

text: What effect does drinking alcohol have on a driver?
options: It increases concentration.
It improves coordination.
It reduces concentration.
It increases awareness.
explanation: Alcohol reduces concentration, judgement, and reaction times.

text: If a motorist or a motorcyclist is taking medication which may affect their driving, what should they do?
options: Drink plenty of water while driving.
Seek medical advice in relation to driving.
Drive slower when under the influence of medication that affects driving.
Drive for short distances only.
explanation: Seek medical advice regarding driving while on medication.

text: What effect does a wet road surface have on a vehicle’s braking ability?
options: It reduces the braking distance of that required on a dry surface.
Modern tyres provide grip on a wet road as effectively as on a dry road.
It makes no difference to the required braking distance.
Generally, it doubles the braking distance of that required on a dry surface.
explanation: Wet roads generally double the braking distance.

text: After overtaking another vehicle, what should a driver do?
options: Continue to signal right for a distance.
Move back in front of the vehicle and reduce speed.
Gradually move back into the left when the vehicle has been passed.
Move immediately into the left after passing the vehicle.
explanation: Signal left and gradually move back to your lane when safe.

text: What would happen if a driver cuts in too soon when overtaking another vehicle?
options: It will force oncoming vehicles to suddenly slow causing danger.
The driver would not need to indicate when moving in.
The safety gap between the vehicles increases.
It would force the other vehicle to suddenly slow or change direction causing danger.
explanation: It forces other road users to brake or change direction dangerously.

text: What stopping distance should a driver allow for when driving in snow or icy conditions?
options: Up to half the normal distance.
The normal distance.
Up to ten times the normal distance.
Twice the normal distance.
explanation: Stopping distances can increase by up to ten times.

text: What clearance should drivers normally allow for when passing parked vehicles?
options: A door width.
The width of an average person.
The width of a side mirror.
A car width.
explanation: Allow at least a door's width.

text: Why does it take longer to stop the vehicle on a wet road?
options: The tyres have less road grip than in dry weather.
The suspension of the vehicle is lighter in wet weather.
The tyres have more grip than in dry weather.
The brake fluid is less effective in wet weather.
explanation: Tyres have less grip on a wet road.

text: What is the effect on the control of the vehicle if there is a film of water between the vehicle’s tyres and the road surface?
options: Steering and braking will be more effective.
Steering will be more effective.
Braking only will be less effective.
Steering and braking will be less effective.
explanation: Aquaplaning reduces steering and braking control significantly.

text: What should a driver do if they encounter loose chippings on a road?
options: Slow down and allow extra clearance to other traffic.
A driver should press their hand against the windscreen.
Increase speed so as to avoid causing damage to the vehicle.
Stop the vehicle until the loose chippings can be removed.
explanation: Slow down and allow extra clearance.

text: What should a driver do when driving in slippery road conditions?
options: Drive at normal speed but allow extra stopping distance.
Maintain a normal distance from the vehicle in front.
Apply the brakes sharply from time to time to test the road surface.
Drive at lower speeds and use gentle acceleration and braking.
explanation: Drive slower and use gentle acceleration/braking.

text: What should a driver do when travelling downhill on snow or ice?
options: Select an appropriate gear and brake gently to control speed.
Use a higher gear than normal in order to avoid wheel spin.
Avoid using the brake and use a high gear.
Keep close to the left and brake sharply to reduce speed.
explanation: Select a lower gear and brake gently.

text: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 50 km/h on a dry road?
options: 55 metres.
15 metres.
25 metres.
5 metres.
explanation: 25 metres (dry, 50 km/h).

text: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 50 km/h on a wet road?
options: 56 metres.
76 metres.
36 metres.
16 metres.
explanation: 36 metres (wet, 50 km/h).

text: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 100 km/h on a dry road?
options: 70 metres.
120 metres.
90 metres.
30 metres.
explanation: 70 metres (dry, 100 km/h).

text: In dry weather how might a driver judge what is a safe following distance to vehicle in front?
options: By allowing at least two vehicle lengths between the vehicles.
Drive at the same speed as the vehicle in front.
Allow a least two vehicle lengths for each kilometre per hour.
By using a fixed point and applying the two second rule.
explanation: Use the two-second rule.

text: In wet weather how might a driver judge what is a safe following distance from the vehicle in front?
options: By allowing at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and the driver’s own vehicle passing a fixed point.
By allowing four vehicle lengths between the vehicles.
By allowing two vehicle lengths between the vehicles.
By allowing at least four seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and the driver’s own vehicle passing a fixed point.
explanation: Allow at least four seconds (double the dry gap).

text: What phrase is recommended for drivers to help them determine a safe distance from the vehicle in front on a dry road?
options: “Only a fool breaks the two second rule.”
“Only a fool breaks the one second rule.”
“Only a fool breaks the four second rule.”
“Only a fool breaks the three second rule.”
explanation: "Only a fool breaks the two second rule."

text: What lights should a driver use when driving in dense fog?
options: Drive with sidelights and hazard warning lights.
Drive with dipped headlights and fog lights.
Drive with full headlights and fog lights.
Drive with sidelights and fog lights.
explanation: Use dipped headlights and fog lights.

text: What are the possible consequences of having incorrectly adjusted headlights?
options: Oncoming road users could be dazzled.
The wattage of the headlights could be reduced.
Visibility could be increased.
The headlights could overheat.
explanation: They may dazzle oncoming traffic.

text: When driving at night and blinded by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, what should a driver do?
options: Look towards the verge and slow down and stop if necessary.
Drive well to the left and maintain normal speed.
Repeatedly flash the headlights to warn the offending driver.
Reduce speed and switch on the full headlights.
explanation: Look towards the verge, slow down, and stop if necessary.

text: A driver has been driving regularly in daylight and must now undertake a journey at night. What should the driver do?
options: Drive at a higher speed than during the day to minimise the chances of falling asleep.
Drive at a higher speed than during the day as traffic is lighter at night.
Drive at a slower speed than in the day as visibility is reduced at night.
Drive at the same speed as during the day as there is no extra danger.
explanation: Drive slower to adjust to reduced visibility.

text: With regard to vehicle speed, what should a driver do when driving at night?
options: Maintain normal vehicle speed and drive with full headlights.
Drive at a higher speed than during the day to reduce the chances of falling asleep.
Drive at a speed that enables the driver to stop within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.
Increase vehicle speed as traffic is lighter at night.
explanation: Drive at a speed that allows stopping within clear distance (100m for main beam).

text: When driving at night, what is the safest approach for a driver to adopt?
options: Drive with full headlights on at all times.
Drive at the maximum speed limit with full headlights on to see clearly ahead.
Drive at the maximum speed limit with dipped headlights on at all times.
Drive at a speed that enables the driver to stop within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.
explanation: Drive at a speed allowing you to stop within the distance you see clear.

text: When is it safe for a driver to use the main beam headlights when driving at night?
options: In built up areas where there is good street lighting.
This practice is not permitted.
When there is no oncoming traffic.
When following a vehicle a short distance ahead.
explanation: In unlit rural areas when there is no oncoming traffic.

text: What lights should a driver have on when driving behind other traffic at night?
options: Side lights.
Dipped headlights.
Main beam headlights.
Front fog lights.
explanation: Dipped headlights.

text: When driving at night, when must a driver use dipped headlights?
options: When there is no oncoming traffic.
When meeting or driving behind other traffic.
When driving at more than 100 km/h.
When driving at less than 50 km/h.
explanation: When meeting or following other traffic.

text: When dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, what should a driver do?
options: Do not look directly at the lights.
Shield their eyes with their hand.
Look at the dashboard momentarily.
Turn their head to the right.
explanation: Do not look directly at lights; glance towards the verge.

text: When should a driver use fog lights on their vehicle?
options: Use fog lights to improve visibility during light rain.
Switch on fog lights as a warning to pedestrians.
Use fog lights only in dense fog and falling snow.
Use fog lights on a badly lit country road.
explanation: Only in dense fog or falling snow.

text: When can a driver expect to encounter black ice?
options: Only late at night.
When the temperature drops close to freezing.
Black ice only occurs on motorways.
Only in the early hours of the morning.
explanation: When temperatures drop close to freezing.

text: What should a driver do if there is black ice on the road?
options: Apply the brakes regularly to prevent them from freezing.
Only use a low gear to improve traction.
Avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration.
Apply the brakes regularly to check road surface.
explanation: Avoid harsh braking, steering, and acceleration.

text: Where is black ice likely to occur on the road?
options: In mild weather on a coastal road.
On a hard shoulder only.
In sheltered or shaded areas.
Only in built-up areas.
explanation: In sheltered or shaded areas.

text: What is the safest practice when driving on icy roads?
options: Drive at normal speed but apply the brakes from time to time to check for grip.
Rely completely on the ABS or other advanced driver assistance systems.
Drive at a slower speed than usual using gentle acceleration and braking.
Drive in a low gear at all times using maximum acceleration.
explanation: Drive slower, use gentle controls. Avoid harsh actions.

text: When driving, what effect could icy roads have on the vehicle?
options: The vehicle would be more likely to skid.
Front tyre pressure increases.
Tyre grip improves in lower temperatures.
Rear tyre pressure increases.
explanation: Increased risk of skidding.

text: What should a driver do when driving in slippery road conditions?
options: Accelerate harder using only the lower gears.
Drive slower than normal keeping a close distance to the vehicle in front.
Use gentle acceleration and braking.
Brake regularly to improve tyre grip.
explanation: Slow down and increase distance.

text: Apart from the risk of skidding, what should the driver be aware of when driving in snow?
options: Road signs and road markings may become obscured.
The power steering fluid may freeze causing the steering to fail.
The air in the tyres may freeze, causing them to burst.
The brake fluid may freeze, causing the brakes to fail.
explanation: Signs and markings may be obscured.

text: What should a driver do when driving in heavy rain?
options: Maintain normal speeds as on a dry road.
Weave the vehicle slightly in order to improve tyre grip.
Increase speed so that the vehicle will glide over any standing water.
Be aware that the vehicle may slide or ‘aquaplane’.
explanation: Slow down and be aware of aquaplaning.

text: What is the danger in driving at high speeds on wet roads?
options: There is no danger provided that the tyre pressure has been reduced to take account of weather conditions.
There is no danger provided that the tyre pressure has been increased to take account of weather conditions.
Danger of ‘aquaplaning’ or sliding across the road surface.
Danger that tyre pressure will automatically increase.
explanation: Danger of aquaplaning and loss of control.

text: What should a driver do when they encounter mud on the road?
options: Change to a lower gear and pump the brakes to see how slippery the surface is.
Apply the brakes immediately and put on the hazard warning lights.
Reduce speed and be aware of farm or works vehicles on the road.
Gradually increase speed so that the mud on the road will not stick to the tyres.
explanation: Slow down; mud increases stopping distance and skid risk.

text: What should a driver do after passing through a flooded section of road?
options: Apply the handbrake gradually to dry out the rear brakes only.
Apply the brake pedal lightly at slow speed for a short distance to dry the brakes.
Increase the speed of the vehicle to dry out the brakes.
Apply the brakes firmly to check if they are still effective.
explanation: Test brakes lightly at slow speed to dry them.

text: What should a driver do where a section of road ahead has a shallow flooded area?
options: Use a high gear and maintain the same speed keeping the engine revs low.
Decrease speed and use a higher gear.
Drive in a low gear as slowly as possible keeping the revs high.
Increase speed and use a higher gear.
explanation: Reduce speed, use low gear, keep revs high.

text: When a driver wants to turn left into a property and there is a bus lane on the left, what should the driver do?
options: Give way to cyclists, taxis and buses which may be using the bus lane.
Give way to cyclists and taxis which may be using the bus lane.
A driver should never turn left across a bus lane.
A driver should give way to buses only.
explanation: Yield to cyclists, taxis, and buses in the lane. Check before turning.

text: What traffic may use a contra-flow bus lane?
options: Buses on a scheduled service.
Buses and motorised wheelchairs only.
Buses, taxis and cyclists.
Buses, taxis and motorcycles.
explanation: Scheduled buses only.

text: What traffic may use a with-flow bus lane during the times specified on information signs at the start of the lane?
options: Vehicles with more than one passenger.
Buses only.
All traffic.
Buses, taxis and cyclists.
explanation: Buses, taxis, and cyclists.

text: When driving along a dual carriageway in normal driving conditions, which lane should a driver be in?
options: In the right-hand lane except when driving a works vehicle or HGV.
In the right-hand lane.
In the left-hand lane unless the driver wishes to overtake or turn right.
In either lane.
explanation: Left-hand lane.

text: What does a 2-plus-1 road have?
options: Two lanes of traffic in one direction and one in the opposite direction.
Barriers between the hard shoulder and the verge.
Barriers between lanes of traffic going in the same direction.
Two lanes for cars and one lane for trucks and buses.
explanation: Two lanes one way, one lane the other, alternating every 2km.

text: What should a driver do when travelling on a motorway or dual carriageway?
options: Relax because there will be no oncoming traffic.
Be alert for other drivers who may suddenly change lanes or reduce speed.
Match the speed to that of the vehicle in front.
Match the speed to that of the vehicle in the adjoining lane.
explanation: Be alert for traffic changing lanes or reducing speed quickly.

text: In normal driving conditions on a motorway, which lane should the driver occupy?
options: Drive in the offside (right-hand) lane as the nearside (left-hand) lane is for HGVs and buses only.
Constantly manoeuvre between whichever lane has the least volume of traffic.
Drive in the offside (right-hand) lane unless intending to take a left exit.
Drive in the nearside (left-hand) lane unless intending to overtake.
explanation: Keep left unless overtaking.

text: What should a driver do when joining a motorway from a slip road?
options: Drive directly onto the motorway as the driver on the acceleration lane has right of way.
Try to match the vehicle speed to that of traffic already on the motorway and merge into it in a suitable gap.
Drive along the hard shoulder until a suitable gap appears in the motorway traffic to allow the driver to merge into it.
Always stop at the end of the acceleration lane and yield to traffic on the motorway.
explanation: Match motorway speed, merge when safe, avoid hard shoulder, yield to traffic.

text: Is a driver permitted to pick up or set down a passenger on a motorway?
options: It is only permitted within 200 metres of a slip-road.
A driver is never permitted to pick up or set down passengers on a motorway.
It is not permitted, except during daylight hours.
It is permitted provided that the driver stops on the hard-shoulder.
explanation: Stopping is illegal and dangerous except in emergencies or when signaled by Gardai.

text: When driving on a motorway, what should a driver do if they miss their exit?
options: Wait on the hard shoulder until a suitable gap appears in traffic from both directions and then cross to the opposite side of the motorway.
Stop on the hard shoulder, switch on their hazard lights and reverse back to the desired exit.
Leave the motorway at the next exit and cross to the other side using the fly-over (or underpass).
Cross to the opposite side of the motorway when there is a suitable gap in the oncoming traffic.
explanation: Go to the next exit and turn back.

text: What should a driver do when entering a slip road after leaving a motorway?
options: There is never a need to adjust speed when on a slip road.
Brake severely when entering the slip road in order to slow down.
Comply with the speed limit on the road the driver is joining.
Always reduce speed gradually for a few kilometres.
explanation: Use deceleration lane, reduce speed, and obey the new speed limit.

text: What should a driver do if they drive past their intended exit by mistake?
options: Stop on the hard shoulder and reverse back to the exit.
Use the emergency telephone to ask for advice.
Drive on and leave at the next exit.
Carefully complete a U-turn.
explanation: Proceed to the next exit.

text: What is the main difference between driving on a motorway and driving on other types of road?
options: Traffic travelling at 120 km/h must only use the outside lane of a motorway.
Traffic is generally permitted to travel at a higher speed on a motorway.
Traffic generally travels at lower speeds on a motorway than on a dual-carriageway.
Learner permit holders must be accompanied by a full licence holder.
explanation: Higher speeds permitted; restrictions on learners and small motorcycles.

text: On a 2-lane motorway, what procedure should a driver adopt when wishing to overtake another vehicle safely?
options: Check for following traffic and overtake in either lane.
Use their mirrors, signal and overtake in the right-hand lane when it is safe to do so.
Use their mirrors, signal and overtake in the left-hand lane only.
Signal, use their mirrors and overtake in any available lane when it is safe to do so.
explanation: Overtake on the right, check mirrors/blind spots, signal, and return to left when safe.

text: What may the hard shoulder of a motorway be used for?
options: Joining the motorway.
Stopping to use a mobile phone.
Stopping in an emergency.
Exiting the motorway.
explanation: Emergency or breakdown only.

text: After exiting the motorway and coming towards a junction at the end of the deceleration lane (slip road) what should a driver do?
options: Maintain motorway speeds to the end of the slip road.
The driver must always stop at the end of a slip road.
The driver should continue at the junction as traffic on the slip road has right of way.
Be alert for oncoming and crossing traffic at the end of the slip road.
explanation: Check for lower speed limits and be alert for bends, junctions, and traffic.

text: A driver wishes to go straight ahead at a cross junction of equal importance. If they encounter other traffic, what is the general rule that applies?
options: Give way to traffic approaching firstly from the left and then the right.
Carry on as normal as they always have the right of way.
Give way to traffic approaching from the left only.
Traffic approaching from the driver’s right has right of way.
explanation: Traffic on the right has right of way.

text: In general, where two lanes are provided on the approach to a roundabout, which lane should a driver select when they intend taking an exit to the right (past the 12 o’clock position) of the roundabout?
options: By straddling both lanes.
Either lane.
The left-hand lane.
The right-hand lane.
explanation: Right lane for exits past 12 o'clock.

text: What position should a driver generally adopt on approach to a roundabout when intending to take the first exit to the left?
options: Approach in the left-hand lane.
Approach by straddling both lanes.
Approach in any lane available.
Approach in the right-hand lane.
explanation: Left lane for the first exit (left).

text: In general, when turning right on a two-way road, where should a driver position the vehicle?
options: At either side of the middle of the road.
At the far left-hand side of the road.
Just left of the middle of the road.
At the far right-hand side of the road.
explanation: Just left of the centre of the road.

text: What should a driver do before turning right from a major road into a minor road?
options: Stop and signal traffic to exit right from the minor road.
Yield right of way to oncoming traffic and to pedestrians crossing at the junction.
Commence turn in front of oncoming traffic as they must yield to traffic turning right.
Stop and signal traffic to exit left from the minor road.
explanation: Yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians crossing.

text: In general, which of the following should a driver do before entering a tunnel?
options: Ensure that full headlights are switched on.
Switch on hazard warning lights to alert other traffic of their presence.
Ensure that dipped headlights are switched on.
Only use dipped headlights if there is other traffic in the tunnel.
explanation: Switch on dipped headlights.

text: What should a driver do when entering a tunnel?
options: Always switch off your radio to avoid distractions.
Drive closer to the vehicle in front.
Never drive below the posted speed limit.
Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front.
explanation: Keep safe distance (50m for cars, 100m for others). No tailgating.

text: What should a driver do if there is very heavy traffic congestion in a tunnel?
options: Switch on hazard warning lights.
Keep close to the vehicle in front.
Leave the vehicle.
Stop at the nearest emergency exit.
explanation: Switch on hazard lights, keep distance, be patient.

text: When stopped at traffic lights and the green light comes on but pedestrians are still crossing the road, what should a driver do?
options: Move forward to encourage them to complete the crossing quickly.
Sound the horn as a warning to them that lights have changed.
Signal the pedestrians that the lights have changed and drive on.
Wait as long as necessary to enable them to complete the crossing.
explanation: Wait for pedestrians to finish crossing.

text: How is a learner driver likely to react in unusual traffic situations?
options: Better than an experienced driver.
Quicker than an experienced driver.
Slower than an experienced driver.
In the same way as an experienced driver.
explanation: Learners may react more slowly to unusual situations.

text: When negotiating junctions, which road users are particularly vulnerable?
options: Minibus drivers.
Van drivers.
Tractor drivers.
Motorcyclists.
explanation: Motorcyclists (less visible).

text: In slow-moving city traffic, a driver should occasionally check their blind spots for which road users in particular?
options: Cars.
Vans.
Cyclists.
Taxis.
explanation: Cyclists (hard to see in blind spots).

text: When driving on a road that has a potholed surface and there is a cyclist ahead, what should a driver do?
options: Allow extra clearance in case the cyclist swerves to avoid a pothole.
Expect the cyclist to keep to the left and maintain speed.
Maintain course and sound the horn to alert the cyclist of their approach.
Change to a lower gear and overtake quickly.
explanation: Give extra clearance; they may swerve to avoid potholes.

text: What should a driver be aware of when making a left turn into a side road?
options: To approach as close to the kerb as possible.
Following traffic must have room to overtake.
Cyclists may come up on the left (nearside).
Cyclists might come up on the right (offside).
explanation: Check for cyclists coming up on the left.

text: When driving on a country road without footpaths, what should a driver expect coming towards them on their side of the road?
options: Tractors.
Pedestrians.
Cyclists.
Motorcyclists.
explanation: Pedestrians walking on the right (facing traffic).

text: What should a driver do when driving at night on an unlit road?
options: Drive close to the left to avoid oncoming traffic.
Watch out for pedestrians wearing dark clothing.
Drive on the centre of the road.
Drive as close as possible to the line of reflective studs.
explanation: Pedestrians in dark clothing. Drive at a speed to stop safely.

text: What procedure should a driver follow when intending to overtake a cyclist travelling in the same direction up ahead?
options: Indicate, move out and check the mirror for following traffic.
Indicate, check the mirror, move out and overtake when safe to do so.
Mirror check, indicate and move out if it is safe to do so.
Mirror check, and move out to overtake without indicating.
explanation: Mirror, Signal, Manoeuvre. Give extra space.

text: What should a driver do when travelling on a country road with following traffic, and they meet pedestrians?
options: Gesture to the pedestrians to move in off the road.
Flash the lights to alert following traffic of a pedestrian on the road.
Leave a minimum clearance of 30 centimetres.
Signal their intention to overtake the pedestrians.
explanation: Check mirrors and signal before moving out to overtake.

text: When driving on dark winter mornings and evenings on unlit country roads, what should a driver be aware of?
options: On country roads, cyclists have space in the margin of the road so that a driver can overtake them without reducing speed or moving out.
Cyclists are much more vulnerable in poor lighting conditions.
Cyclists all wear reflective belts, have the correct lighting on their bicycles and are clearly visible.
An oncoming cyclist could never be dazzled by the vehicle lights and wobble off course into the driver’s path.
explanation: Cyclists/pedestrians are harder to see.

text: When driving on dark winter mornings and evenings on unlit country roads, what should a driver be aware of?
options: That there will be no pedestrians walking on the road.
That all pedestrians will be wearing reflective armbands and bright clothing.
That there could be vulnerable pedestrians walking on the road.
That the lack of light will not affect the driver’s ability to see vulnerable pedestrians.
explanation: Vulnerable users like pedestrians may be on the road.

text: When driving on dark winter mornings and evenings on unlit country roads, what should a driver be aware of?
options: That a driver should drive at all times with sidelights on in order to see pedestrians walking on unlit country roads.
Schoolchildren are more vulnerable on unlit country roads on dark winter mornings and evenings.
A driver should expect that pedestrians will be on the footpath and not be in danger of being hit.
That the lack of light will not effect the driver’s ability to see stray animals on the road.
explanation: Schoolchildren are more vulnerable.

text: What should a driver do if a front tyre bursts while driving?
options: Relax the hold on the steering wheel.
Grip the steering wheel firmly.
Apply the handbrake immediately.
Brake firmly and quickly.
explanation: Grip wheel firmly, slow gradually, stop safely.

text: What precautions could a driver take against the risk of fire in their vehicle?
options: Avoid driving the vehicle with a full tank of fuel.
Keep all water levels filled to the maximum at all times.
Carry a suitable fire extinguisher in the vehicle.
Use low-octane unleaded petrol in the vehicle.
explanation: Carry a fire extinguisher.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle is broken down on a motorway and they are awaiting assistance?
options: Stand out on the roadway and direct traffic to pass.
Switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights, get out of the vehicle and stand safely to the side.
Get out of the vehicle and wait at the rear of it.
Try to flag down other traffic from the rear of the vehicle for assistance.
explanation: Use hazard lights, get out, stand clear/safe.

text: What does this dial provide information on?
options: Fuel level.
Gearbox revolution.
Oil level.
Engine revolution.
explanation: Engine revolution.

text: What does a rev counter provide information on?
options: Engine revolutions.
Gear box revolutions.
Wheel revolutions.
Heater-fan revolutions.
explanation: Engine revolutions.

text: What should the driver be able to see in the vehicle mirrors when they are properly adjusted?
options: The passenger area of the vehicle.
The position of all the wheels.
The position of the left-side wheels.
The area behind and to each side of the vehicle.
explanation: Area behind and to each side.

text: What should the driver be able to see in the exterior mirrors of a vehicle when they are properly adjusted?
options: The sides of the vehicle only.
60% angled to the vehicle and 40% to the road.
The area to each side of the vehicle.
The back of the vehicle only.
explanation: Area to each side of the vehicle.

text: The vehicle’s exterior mirrors are covered by a film of mud and dust. What should the driver do?
options: Angle the mirrors towards the front for a distance in order to clean them.
Clean them with a cloth or tissue before starting their journey.
Drive in the slip stream of other traffic, as this will eventually clean the mirrors.
Continue on and clean them after reaching the destination.
explanation: Clean them before starting the journey.

text: What effect can wet weather have on a vehicle’s exterior mirrors?
options: Water droplets can make the reflected object appear closer than it really is.
Water droplets help to keep them clean.
Water can cause a short-circuit in the electrically heated mirrors.
Water droplets can obscure the reflected image.
explanation: Water droplets can obscure the view.

text: What does blue smoke coming from the vehicle’s exhaust generally mean?
options: The catalytic converter is worn out.
The engine is burning oil.
The air filter needs to be replaced.
The engine is overheating.
explanation: Engine is burning oil.

text: What is the effect of a worn exhaust?
options: The filtering of fumes is reduced and engine noise is louder.
Fuel efficiency is increased as the fumes escape more quickly.
Gear-changing is more difficult.
The engine overheats.
explanation: Reduced fume filtering and increased noise.

text: What effect can a faulty exhaust system have?
options: It can increase the vehicle’s noise and pollution levels.
It can reduce the vehicle’s engine noise.
It can increase wear on the vehicle’s engine.
It can improve the vehicle’s fuel consumption.
explanation: Increased noise and pollution.

text: What is the purpose of a catalytic converter?
options: It allows the engine to quickly reach its normal operating temperature.
It increases engine power.
It decreases engine power.
It filters exhaust gases and reduces air pollution.
explanation: Filters exhaust gases to reduce pollution.

text: How does harsh acceleration affect fuel consumption?
options: There is no effect provided the engine is properly tuned.
There is no effect if a high gear is engaged.
Fuel consumption decreases.
Fuel consumption increases.
explanation: Fuel consumption increases.

text: How does continuous high-speed driving affect fuel consumption?
options: It reduces fuel consumption as long as the road is straight.
It reduces fuel consumption.
It increases fuel consumption.
It uses the same consumption of fuel as lower speed driving.
explanation: Increases fuel consumption.

text: How can fuel efficiency be improved?
options: By using an anti-waxing agent only in freezing conditions.
By accelerating hard up through the gears to reach the desired speed as quickly as possible.
By using gentle acceleration and making gear changes appropriate to speed.
By driving the vehicle in a lower gear for as long as possible.
explanation: Gentle acceleration and appropriate gear changes.

text: What effect does a worn exhaust have on a vehicle?
options: It causes the water coolant to leak from the engine.
It causes noise and gas pollution levels to increase.
It decreases fuel consumption.
It causes oil to leak on the road.
explanation: Increased noise and gas pollution.

text: When is the use of the horn prohibited?
options: Between 11:30 pm and 6:00 am on any road.
At all times in a built-up area.
Between 10:00 pm and 6:00 am in a built-up area.
Between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am in a built-up area.
explanation: Between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am in built-up areas.

text: What can a driver do to maximise fuel efficiency while driving?
options: Reduce pressure in all tyres.
Avoid carrying unnecessary weight.
Fit a roof rack.
Increase road speed.
explanation: Avoid carrying unnecessary weight.

text: Which action is likely to cause an increase in fuel consumption?
options: Driving at a constant speed.
Harsh acceleration.
Turning off air conditioning.
Looking ahead and anticipating traffic flow.
explanation: Harsh acceleration.

text: How are emergency vehicles identified?
options: By continuously lit red lights.
By flashing green lights.
By flashing amber and white lights.
By flashing red or blue lights.
explanation: Be extra careful and yield if safe.

text: After a heavy downpour, why should a driver keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front?
options: Because tyre grip improves when wet.
Because wheels rotate at a greater speed after rain.
Because wheels rotate at a slower speed after rain.
Because the required stopping distances is greater.
explanation: Tyre grip is reduced, increasing stopping distance. Slow down and increase following distance.

text: At traffic lights, a driver should take particular care for which road users coming up on the left?
options: Tractors.
Motorcyclists.
Vans.
Cars.
explanation: Check for cyclists and motorcyclists on the left.

text: When a driver intends to make a left-hand turn at a junction where there are pedestrians and cyclists present, what should a driver do?
options: Sound the horn while proceeding to warn the other road users of the intention to turn.
Check your mirrors and watch for cyclists or pedestrians on the left.
Check the right-hand mirror, make the turn and then signal.
Signal left, watch the right-hand mirror and make the turn.
explanation: Watch for vulnerable road users; they have equal right to safety.

text: Which of the following road users are most vulnerable in slow-moving city traffic?
options: Cars.
Taxis.
Motorcyclists.
Vans.
explanation: Motorcyclists (hard to see in blind spots).

text: Which of the following road users are most vulnerable in slow-moving city traffic?
options: Cars.
Taxis.
Vans.
Pedestrians.
explanation: Pedestrians (hard to see in blind spots).

text: What should a driver do when driving at night on an unlit road?
options: Watch out for unlit cyclists.
Drive close to the left and switch on front fog lights.
Drive at least 30 km/h below the posted speed limit.
Keep well out from the left-hand side of the road.
explanation: Drive at a speed to stop safely within the distance you can see.

text: What can be achieved by the driving style known as ‘Eco-Driving’?
options: Improved road safety.
Reduced journey times.
Increased journey times.
Increased emissions.
explanation: Improved safety, fuel usage, and emissions. Better anticipation reduces harsh braking/acceleration.

text: What can be achieved by the driving style known as ‘Eco-Driving’?
options: Increased fuel consumption.
Increased journey times.
Increased emissions.
Increased fuel efficiency.
explanation: Increased fuel efficiency, reduced emissions, improved safety.

text: Which action contributes to eco-driving?
options: Maintaining a steady speed.
Braking harshly.
Driving with the windows open.
Driving in a low gear at high speed.
explanation: Steady speed efficiency. Anticipation reduces harsh braking/acceleration.

text: Which action contributes to eco-driving?
options: Driving in a low gear at high speed.
Braking harshly.
Looking ahead and anticipating.
Reducing tyre pressure.
explanation: Anticipation reduces harsh driving.

text: When a driver intends to make a left-hand turn on a busy city street junction and there are pedestrians and cyclists around, what should the driver do?
options: Signal left, watch the right-hand mirror and make the turn when it is clear.
Stay close to the left to prevent cyclists or pedestrians coming up on your left side.
Watch for cyclists or pedestrians who may try to cross the road in front of the vehicle.
Keep to the right to make room for cyclists to pass.
explanation: Watch for pedestrians/cyclists who may appear unexpectedly.

text: Before exiting the vehicle on a busy road, what should the driver ensure?
options: That the gear lever is in neutral.
That the wheels are positioned straight ahead.
Before opening the door the driver should check it is safe to do so.
That the passengers open their door first.
explanation: Check it is safe before opening the door.

text: When towing a high and wide-bodied trailer what should a driver do?
options: Drive with hazard warning lights flashing at all times.
Make use of extended mirrors to check for following traffic.
Drive with a red flag to the front right-hand side of the trailer.
Drive with a red flag at the rear left of the trailer.
explanation: Use extended mirrors for better visibility.

text: If the vehicle’s windows are covered with ice, what should the driver do?
options: Fully clear ice from all windows.
Drive slowly until the heater and demister have cleared the ice.
Use boiling water to clear the ice.
Clear enough space in the windscreen to be able to see ahead.
explanation: Clear all windows of ice for full visibility.

text: What should a driver do if the vehicle’s windows and mirrors are covered in ice?
options: Drive at a reduced speed until the heating system has cleared the ice.
Switch on the heating system and use a scraper to clear the ice before driving.
Use boiling water with salt to clear the ice.
Switch on the windscreen wipers.
explanation: Clear all windows and mirrors of ice.

text: What specific observations should a driver make before reversing their vehicle?
options: Look over both shoulders and behind.
Look over right-hand shoulder.
Look in door mirrors only.
Look in interior mirror only.
explanation: Look over both shoulders and behind to ensure safety.

text: What specific observations should a driver make before reversing a vehicle fitted with an external audible warning device?
options: Observations should be made by opening the driver’s door and looking behind.
Observations should be made only in blind spots.
Observations should be made to the front, sides and rear of the vehicle, including blind spots.
No specific observations needed, as bystanders will be aware of the vehicle.
explanation: Check front, sides, rear, and blind spots yourself.

text: What should a driver do when they intend to reverse into a side road?
options: Focus totally on the left-side door mirror while reversing.
Check carefully all around before and during the reverse.
Open the left-side door fully to look behind.
Angle the door mirrors down before reversing.
explanation: Check all around, especially for pedestrians/traffic behind.

text: What should a driver do if they intend to reverse their vehicle into an area which they cannot see?
options: Open driver’s window and look behind.
Open driver’s door and look behind.
Ask someone to guide you when reversing.
Look in nearside (left) mirror when reversing.
explanation: Get assistance/guide if you cannot see.

text: What should a driver do in order to keep alert during a long journey?
options: Increase speed to shorten the journey.
Keep the radio turned on and windows closed.
Increase the air circulation and stop if necessary.
Turn up the heater to maintain driver comfort.
explanation: Take regular breaks, walk, caffeine, and fresh air.

text: When should rear fog lights be used?
options: In dense fog or falling snow.
Only in light fog.
When the vehicle behind is too close.
Always when driving at night in an unlit area.
explanation: Only in dense fog or falling snow.

text: When should rear fog lights be used?
options: When driving in dense fog or falling snow.
Rear fog lights should always be used.
When both the rear tail lights are broken.
Rear fog lights should be used only at dawn and dusk.
explanation: Only in dense fog or falling snow.

text: What should a driver do if dazzled by headlights reflecting in the rear-view mirror of their car?
options: Use the night driving mode on their rear-view mirror.
Adjust the mirror to reflect the light back towards the following driver.
Switch the lights off and on to remind the following driver to dip their lights.
Turn on the rear fog lights to signal to the following vehicle to turn off their headlights.
explanation: Adjust rear-view mirror to night driving mode.

text: At night, what effect could driving with a single headlight have on oncoming drivers?
options: It could dazzle them.
They could mistake the vehicle for a motorcycle.
It could enable them to see the vehicle more clearly.
It would have no effect on oncoming drivers.
explanation: One headlight could be mistaken for a motorcycle's position.

text: What is meant by the term jack-knifing?
options: When the trailer is too heavy to be drawn by the tractor.
When the vehicle slides due to ice or water on the road.
When the jack is not strong enough to lift an axle.
When the trailer is travelling faster than the drawing vehicle.
explanation: Trailer pivots around hitch during sharp braking, causing loss of control.

text: When should a driver use the vehicle side lights?
options: When driving in foggy conditions.
When parking at all times.
When driving in an unlit area at night.
When parking on an unlit road.
explanation: Leave parking lights on to be seen.

text: What is a possible effect of over-filling the engine with oil?
options: It could burst the oil filter.
It could damage the oil pump.
It could damage the catalytic converter.
It could reduce the oil pressure.
explanation: Damages catalytic converter and increases emissions.

text: What safety precaution should a driver take when getting out of their vehicle?
options: Check all around for approaching traffic and pedestrians before opening the door.
Ensure the gear lever is in neutral.
Open the door and try to get out as speedily as possible.
Ensure all valuables are secured and out of sight.
explanation: Check for traffic/pedestrians/cyclists. Exit when safe.

text: On a busy road, how should a driver allow passengers out of a vehicle?
options: Stop and allow them to get out from whichever side of the vehicle they are sitting.
Stop and allow them to get out on the side nearest the kerb.
Stop and encourage them to get out as quickly as possible.
Signal to following traffic to overtake before allowing the passengers to get out.
explanation: Passengers should exit on the kerb side.

text: How should a driver apply the brakes in an emergency if the vehicle is fitted with anti-lock brakes (ABS)?
options: Press the brake pedal only lightly.
Press the brake pedal firmly and hold.
Press and release the brake at rapid intervals.
Press and release the brake at slow intervals.
explanation: Brake firmly. ABS maintains steering control.

text: What effect could a front-tyre blow-out have on a vehicle?
options: The wheels will lock up and stop rotating.
The steering wheel will stay in the straight on position.
The steering wheel will pull to one side.
Anti-lock brakes will be automatically disengaged.
explanation: Steering pulls to the side of the blowout.

text: What should a driver do when suddenly confronted by a hazard on the road?
options: Decelerate and apply the footbrake firmly.
Slowly brake and switch off the ignition.
Apply the handbrake and the footbrake together.
Depress clutch and switch off the ignition.
explanation: Brake firmly, maintain pressure. Clutch just before stopping.

text: When driving along and required to stop suddenly, what should a driver do?
options: Depress the clutch and then apply the handbrake.
Apply the handbrake and the footbrake together.
Apply the footbrake firmly.
Steer sharply to one side and apply the handbrake.
explanation: Brake firmly, maintain pressure. Clutch just before stopping.

text: When required to stop in an emergency, what should a driver do?
options: Press the footbrake and engage a higher gear.
Apply both the clutch and handbrake.
Apply firm pressure on the footbrake.
Apply gentle pressure to the footbrake.
explanation: Brake firmly, maintain pressure. Clutch just before stopping.

text: When required to stop in an emergency, what should a driver do?
options: Apply the footbrake firmly.
Switch off the ABS system.
Apply the footbrake and engage a higher gear.
Depress the clutch pedal and engage a lower gear.
explanation: Brake firmly, maintain pressure. Clutch just before stopping.

text: What can a driver do to stay alert on a long journey?
options: Roll down the window and allow fresh air in.
Stop, park in a safe place and have a cup of coffee.
Turn up the temperature in the vehicle.
Listen attentively to the radio.
explanation: Stop in a safe place, caffeine, 15 min nap.

text: What effect can wet weather have on the vehicle’s exterior mirrors?
options: It has no effect.
It can short-circuit the electrically heated mirrors.
It can keep them clean.
It can distort the rear vision of the driver.
explanation: Water obscures view. Use heated mirrors or clear manually.

text: What should a driver do before starting a journey in bad weather?
options: Reduce tyre pressure to ensure better grip on the road.
Top up the windscreen washer reservoir.
Increase tyre pressure to ensure better grip on the road.
Top up the gearbox with coolant.
explanation: Ensure sufficient windscreen washer fluid.

text: What should a driver do to secure the vehicle before leaving it?
options: Apply the exhaust brake and switch off the engine.
Leave the engine running with the parking brake on.
Apply the parking brake and switch off the engine.
Leave the engine running with the exhaust brake on.
explanation: Apply parking brake, engine off, check safety exiting.

text: Before entering a tunnel, what should a driver do in order to improve vision?
options: Wear sunglasses to prevent glare from the lights.
Take off sunglasses.
Drive close to the vehicle in front.
Pull down the visor to eliminate overhead light glare.
explanation: Remove sunglasses.

text: When a vehicle is stopped in a tunnel due to congestion what should a driver do?
options: Walk to the nearest emergency exit.
Switch off the engine and leave the vehicle.
Keep close to the vehicle in front.
Switch on hazard warning lights.
explanation: Keep safe distance, switch on hazard lights.

text: When a vehicle is stopped in a tunnel due to congestion what should a driver do?
options: Switch on the fog lights.
Switch off the engine.
Only give hand signals.
Keep the engine ticking over in a low gear.
explanation: Switch off engine to reduce fumes.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?
options: Hitch a lift to the nearest service area and get help.
Flag down a passing motorist and ask for help.
Use the emergency telephone to call for help.
Walk to the end of the tunnel to call the Gardaí.
explanation: Engine off, hazards on, use emergency phone.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?
options: Wait in the vehicle for help to arrive.
Beckon other traffic to overtake.
Reverse the vehicle to the exit.
Switch on the hazard warning lights.
explanation: Engine off, hazards on, use emergency phone.

text: If a vehicle being driven through a tunnel goes on fire, what should the driver do?
options: Leave the vehicle immediately and use the emergency phone at the nearest emergency station.
Stay in the vehicle and phone the emergency station to report the fire.
Drive to the nearest emergency exit as quickly as possible.
Wait for the tunnel traffic radio to announce the fire drill.
explanation: Engine off, leave immediately, use emergency phone, exit tunnel.

text: When joining a motorway from a slip road, what should a driver do?
options: Adjust speed to match that of the motorway traffic, and merge into a suitable gap.
Drive on the hard shoulder for a distance until a suitable gap appears in the traffic.
Stop on the slip road until a suitable gap appears in the traffic.
Use the size of the vehicle to assert its position on the motorway.
explanation: Match speed, merge into gap in lane 1.

text: What would a lightness in the steering MOST likely indicate?
options: Gravelled surface.
Icy surface.
Smooth surface.
Wet surface.
explanation: Loss of traction (likely ice). Increase braking distance.

text: What are the drink driving penalties for a learner driver with a blood alcohol concentrate (BAC) of 20 mg to 80 mg per 100 millilitres of blood?
options: €200 fine and 5 penalty points.
€200 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 3 penalty points.
explanation: Illegal to drive above limits. Alcohol affects judgement.

text: What are the drink driving penalties for a professional driver holding a full car licence and found to have a blood alcohol concentrate (BAC) of 20 mg to 80 mg per 100 millilitres of blood?
options: €100 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
The penalties only apply over 80 mg (BAC).
There are no penalties below 50 mg (BAC).
explanation: Illegal to drive above limits. Alcohol affects judgement.

text: What are the drink driving penalties for a driver with a blood alcohol concentrate (BAC) of 80 mg to 100 mg per 100 millilitres of blood?
options: €200 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
€400 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
€400 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
explanation: Illegal to drive above limits. Alcohol affects judgement.

text: What is the penalty for a driver who refuses to give breath, blood or urine samples as evidence for a second offence to An Gárda Síochána?
options: Automatic disqualification for 12 months.
Automatic disqualification for 3 months.
Automatic disqualification for 4 years.
Automatic disqualification for 6 years.
explanation: Illegal to drive above limits. Offence to refuse sample.

text: Can An Gárda Síochána conduct roadside testing for drugs and alcohol in the mornings?
options: They can check for alcohol only.
They can check for drugs only.
No, they can’t check until after midday.
Yes, they can check at any time.
explanation: Intoxicants include alcohol and drugs (including medicines).

text: Along with an impairment test, what may a Garda request if they suspect a driver of driving under the influence of drugs?
options: An insurance certificate.
A saliva sample.
A driver’s licence.
A breath sample.
explanation: If a driver is stopped at a roadside check, they should be aware that, along with the impairment test, Gardaí can also request a saliva sample if they suspect the driver is driving under the influence of drugs.

text: What is the maximum penalty on conviction for drug driving?
options: €5,000 fine and 6 months in prison.
€3,000 fine and 12 months driving disqualification.
€3,000 fine and 12 months in prison.
€5,000 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
explanation: Severe penalties apply. Drug driving is extremely dangerous.

text: Do the limits for drink and drug driving differ if detected in the morning?
options: Yes, they are lower in the mornings.
No, unless tested after 10:00 am.
Yes, they are higher in the evening.
No, they are the same at all times.
explanation: Limits are constant. Intoxicants remain in the body; morning driving may still be illegal.

text: What should a driver do when an emergency service vehicle approaches with flashing blue lights?
options: Increase speed to prevent obstructing the emergency service vehicle.
React quickly, safely and carefully to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
Brake suddenly to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
Do nothing and ignore the emergency service vehicle.
explanation: React quickly, safely, and carefully to let them pass.

text: What should a driver never do when an emergency service vehicle approaches with flashing blue lights?
options: React quickly, safely and carefully to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
Clear the way as soon as possible.
Brake suddenly or block the road.
Pull over in a place which has enough space for the emergency service vehicle to pass safely.
explanation: React quickly, safely, and carefully to let them pass.

text: Can a driver break a red light or break the speed limit to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass?
options: Yes, a driver may break the speed limit to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
No, a driver should never break a red light or speed up to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
No, except where the junction or road is clear, then a driver can break a red light or speed up to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
Yes, a driver may legally break a red light to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
explanation: React safely to let them pass. You cannot break red lights or speed limits.

text: If it is safe to overtake a cyclist in speed zones up to 50 km/h, what is the recommended minimum passing distance?
options: Allow a maximum of 1 metre.
Allow a maximum of 1.75 metres.
Allow a minimum of 1.75 metres.
Allow a minimum of 1 metre.
explanation: Give recommended clearance based on speed limit when safe to overtake.

text: If it is safe to overtake a cyclist in speed zones over 50 km/h, what is the recommended minimum passing distance?
options: Allow a maximum of 1.75 metres.
Allow a minimum of 1 metre.
Allow a maximum of 1.5 metres.
Allow a minimum of 1.5 metres.
explanation: Give recommend clearance based on speed limit when safe to overtake.

text: How can a pedestrian walking along a poorly lit road reduce the risk of an accident occurring?
options: Walk as part of a group.
Wear dark clothing.
Walk on the left-hand side of the road.
Wear high-visibility clothing.
explanation: Wear bright/hi-vis clothing during day, reflective at night.

text: What is a courtesy pedestrian crossing?
options: An uncontrolled pedestrian crossing place.
A pedestrian crossing with flashing amber lights.
A pedestrian crossing on a pedestrian street.
A pedestrian crossing with ‘look right’ painted on the roadway.
explanation: Uncontrolled crossing. Verify traffic sees you. Drivers should approach slowly.

text: What is the likely effect of motorists ‘rubbernecking’ at the scene of a traffic incident?
options: It can cause additional incidents as drivers become distracted.
It allows traffic to change course without attention.
It allows traffic to change speed without attention.
It can increase traffic flow near an incident.
explanation: Rubbernecking distracts drivers, causing traffic jams and collisions.

text: How should a driver react to emergency services vehicles with flashing blue lights and/or sirens on?
options: Brake suddenly and stop to avoid causing obstruction.
Check their mirrors before looking for space to move aside.
Mount kerb on offside of the road to make room.
Only move aside if it is an ambulance.
explanation: Check mirrors, signal, and pull over safely to let them pass.

text: What is the penalty for a vehicle owner who allows a learner driver to drive their vehicle unaccompanied?
options: They will incur 2 penalty points on their licence.
They will be fined €2,000.
Their vehicle will be seized.
They will lose their driving licence.
explanation: Vehicle may be seized if learner drives unaccompanied.

text: A learner permit driver who receives 7 penalty points in a 36 month period (three years) will be banned from driving for how many months?
options: 9 months.
6 months.
